The only nitpicks I have with the game are:  A) The boss fights are dreadfully easy once you get a hang of the game. B) There is a certain enemy type towards the end of the game that felt really cheap to me (though that may just be because I was worse at the game than I thought). C) I'm not sure how I came under the impression, but I thought 'Recursion Mode' (New Game+) would include extra story elements or different dialogue in certain areas. After a bit of research after finishing the game, I discovered it was nearly all enemy layouts and enemy difficulty and such, much to my dismay. Though if you're into the combat, I suppose that's not really a negative. D) My game crashed. Once. In a challenge map. Before it began. After the game saved. No biggy, but something to watch out for.  Overall, absolutely amazing game that will stick with me for a while, and may very well become one of my favourite games. I whole-heartedly recommend buying it, especially if you enjoyed Bastion. Even if you didn't, buy it anyways, Supergiant deserves all of your money.  10/10 would bang, play, finish, get upset by, reason with myself so I stop getting upset by and then write a review that got way longer than I intended again.

This game met the expectations beset by Bastion: better combat, the same great narration we have come to expect from the likes of Logan Cunningham, the amazing music provided by Ashely Barrett and Darren Korb, and a high-calliber story to boot.  But, comparisons invited need adressing: -The story is different, but not in a bad way, because it is an entirely different story: Bastion was more of a world-focused, mini-epic, and Transistor is closer to a film noir. It is more of a personal journey of the titular character Red, and the voice trapped in the Transistor. I still feel that there are some themes(especially towards the end) that seem a bit similar to Bastion, but on the whole, it is a different story. It is still great, especially if you can enjoy something nuanced.  -The combat is a bit heavy to begin with, but it is a joy to experiment with. It is built in such a way that you can employ any strategy you wish to, without making the game too easy or too hard: I often found myself using Jaunt(a dodge/dash move) as my primary damage output, and I wasn't punished for it, which is nice. I still think that whilst its preferrable to utilise the Turn() mechanic, it is entirely possible to use only the real time part of the combat. There are enough cooldown modifying abilities that you could unleash entire barrages at the enemy without having to go into Turn().  Aside from that, well the music is a bit more cyber-punk, as goes with the setting, but it did satisfy me more than Bastion's soundtrack. However, that is due to my own preferences in music. The art style is still as gorgeous as it was before, and the enemy design and variation are also pretty good.  Overall, it is definitely worth your time: it improved in Bastion in its gameplay, the story is brilliant, and everything else is of the same(if not greater) standard than the studio's previous title. It is well worth the asking price, because it is that damn good.

I have a hard time explaining how deeply in love I am with this game. It's a masterpiece.  (Spoiler Free)  The first thing that hits you is the world, and the art, and throughout my entire thirteen hours (on my first playthrough) the environments never get stale or old. Everything is gorgeous and feels handpainted.  The story and the characters are incredible and deeply engaging, but I won't say anything more than that all the voice actors involved are phenomenal.  Battles are fun, fluid, and tactical. The mixture between the strategy and turn-based combat and something more real-time never gets old. Bastion this is not, Transistor is more methodical, and much slower. You're allowed to take your time to plan out what you'd like to do and put it into action. The skills and abilities system keeps the variety up. Usually I'd find my niche and stick to what I liked, but Transistor had me switching up my abilities at every single checkpoint, and not just for all of the files that I was addicted to collecting to get every single tidbit I could out of the writing.  This noir wouldn't be complete without the jazzy cyberpunk soundtrack, which I could listen to forever and never get bored of. Not only is it good on it's own, but it sinks itself deep into the game and plays dynamically and reactively depending on what is happening at the moment.  But, above all else, what makes Transistor a masterpiece is the atmosphere. The absolute dedication the game has to it's world and how much it sucks you in at every opportunity. Optional environments and points of interest litter every single map just to get another line or two out of the Voice. The way the music works itself in, the way enemies interact with you and all your abilities, the way the environments twist and change, the terminals you find, the files you can read, and the small interactions and character moments out of Red herself are unlike anything I have ever played before. If I were making a 'Videogames as art' list, this would top it off.  I will never forget this game.

TL;DR: Everything is either excellent or above average. Get it.  Ok, so here's the review. I love this game, and it's one of my favorites. I'm going to do a run down of each part of the game.  POSSIBLY LIGHT SPOILERS WARNING  Overview: Like Supergiant's last game, Bastion, Transistor is an isometric hack-and slasher with a good story and narrator. Story can be a little bit pretentious, but the combat provides a solid core and everything else is either excellent or good enough that I can reccomend this.  Combat: This is what you'll be doing most of the time. While it starts off relativley simple, it gains depth as you aquire more Functions (your skills) from corpses you find. The main 'gimmick' (but it's not really a gimmick) is being able to freeze time and plan what moves you'll use. You can freeze time, jump behind an enemy, and get a backstab with a melee ability. The combat is a bit complex, but you'll get the hang of it. You (eventually) get four active Function slots, each which can be buffed with two more Functions, and on top of that you can have 2 (or possibly 4 but that's hard to do) passive Functions. The only way to get story documents about corpses which gave you functions is to use the functions as an active, equiping another skill with it, and using it as a passive. This encourages trying new things with the combat. There are also things called Limiters, which you unlock over time. Equiping one makes the game harder, and tells you about the enemy it corresponds with. Combat: 8.5/10  Story: The story is really good if you can figure out what's going on. The characters are mostly given depth through their Functions, because the only characters that talk are three of the villains and your sword. Red, the main character, is a singer who lost her voice because of the villains, which is all I can say without spoiling anything. The sword, getting to talk the most, is the most developed character, but Red is still the favorite of most fans. The story is great, but very confusing without reading some of the community's threads. It regards the cyberpunk city of Cloudbank, where the citizens democratically control what the sky looks like, what the weather is, and what buildings are constructed. (Can't say how without spoilers.) But patterns develop, and the system designed to bring novelty results in nothing changing. This leads to a terrorist orginization of Cloudbank's administrators killing off artists and the people who change the city, and eventually they release an evil called the Process on Cloudbank. The ending of the story is a gut-punch moment. Story: 8/10  Aesthetic:  While the art is great, it's nothing compared tO THE MUSIC IT'S AMAZING. (There are people who bought this game for the soundtrack and still haven't played it.) Aesthetic: 10/10  So if you're looking for a short, replayable story based (slightly pretentious) hack and slasher with the greatest soundtrack of any game ever (seriously), Transistor is the game for you.  Overall: 8.83

I liked this game, but it was primarily due to the combat style. It uses a combination of turn-based and real-time. The player gets to decide how to handle combat. Does the player use TB or RT? Most of the time I used turn-based. Sure, I could attempt to play it like Bastion, but playing by turn gives some added benefits.   The storyline leaves much to be desired. I found it to be full of plot holes and towards the end, it seemed rush and slapped together. Up to that point, I found it intriguing. However, it really loses the player towards the end.   Additionally, the difficulty curve of the game was a bit uneven in spots. From what I found, the player would be engaged with somewhat challenging opponents and then, suddenly, would have to take on a boss that was much, much more difficult than what the player had dealt with prior. After that point, the level of challenge never really peaked beyond the difficulty of that boss - not even the last boss.   Should you get it? Well, that depends. Did you like the music in Bastion? Do you like linear, but somewhat engaging storylines? Will the better aspects of the game (e.g. combat, music) outweigh the not-so-great?  The good: Great music Different style of combat Nice art style Mysterious storyline Great narration  The bad: Still a bit glitchy after a couple of dev patches Predictable storyline Uneven difficulty curve

Transistor may be the classiest, most stylish and   beautiful   game I've ever played. It also seems very innovative. It's an evolution on the super-saturated acrylic painting style of Bastion (Supergiant's previous game), incorporating an intricate 1920s art deco interpretation of neon turquoise Tron glow, visually somewhat similar to Bioshock.  The sound track is an integral part of the beauty. Not at all just background noise, it's closely integrated into the context. It's smoothly haunting with the protagonist character humming soulfully along at the push of a button (strangle compelling).  This game quite closely resembles it's predecessor in many ways:   Both are top down, isometric view.     Poignant, with pretty little side-on 2D cutscenes that augment the in-play storytelling.    Tales of personal loss and societal/city devastation, picking up (or picking through) the pieces.    Disembodied voice-over narration from another character, but one who's physically present in context this time.     Mute protagonist, again an explanation is worked in here excellently.     There are unlocks that make play harder (for slightly more experience gain), as well as collecting new abilities.  But it departs from Bastion's pure, practised skill - aim and click, continuously rolling action bonanza - by injecting a kind of seamless turn planning mechanism into the real time action. This allows, and demands, far more tactical thinking in the heat of battles. It's rewarding as you can escape tight spots in style and beat heavy odds. Plus, of course, this gives plenty of time to stop, think and analyse the situation. Great for those of us who don't always quite have the mental processing speed of fighter pilots.  The abilities, known as ' functions ', form the core of the game experience. They are not only used as novel new active attacks, but also modifier upgrades to   any other   ability you have. Or, as a passive abilities that are always active. Thus there is a combinatorial explosion of possibilities as you proceed to accumulate them.  The huge, buried depth of game mechanics (that must have taken a whole lot of careful design and coding) reminds me most of Magicka's spell system. There, elements are combined in real time to be blasted out like guitar chords. But composing new Transistor skill combinations is a separate setup process done at ' Access Point ' checkpoints. I found all the descriptions a little hard to juggle mentally while shuffling between the different information screens. It's also time consuming, and a little bit more fiddly than necessary, taking me at least as long, overall, as the actual fighting. So probably too long, unless this suits your mindset somewhat, with the play flow thoroughly interrupted. The game is all about figuring out synergistic load-outs and combo strategies.  Players are incentivised to try out many combinations, since there are narrative expanding character biography snippets which are unlocked by using each new ability once (in combat) in each of the 3 types of slot. There's also opportunities to quickly test out ideas and practice, away from the main story progression, in a literal beach themed ' Sandbox ' area. So you're unlikely to stick to one favourite setup for long. It would be real shame and I'm not sure how much that would even be possible. The battles are quite varied, so will often demand quite different approaches. Enemy types are randomly varied to an extent too, on each re-try (or re-play).  Each ability embodies archetypal personality traits of a particular character and they are woven into the story ark to be picked up along the way. It's pretty clever, and really gives a sense of double meaning, that everything and everyone is a metaphor for parts of a computer system, perhaps, like (the original) Tron. Programming functions personified, or vice versa.  The plot sets out like ' Kill Bill ' (2003), but, as details are incrementally expanded via a variety of interactions, a very nuanced exploration of big societal themes is rendered, with the antagonists being sympathetic, tragic and their purpose and motivations understandable. At large, it is a reflection on the potential flaws of an absolute (participatory) democracy, even in an otherwise utopian environment. Here, the 'Process' (collective name for the robot enemies) also feels duplicitous - sounding almost like they are talking about understanding (and subverting) the politic process. Then, of course, the dangers of concentrated power - how small personal flaws might cause everything to unravel. Here, ' The Camerata ' has resonance, to me, of the Khmer Rouge, or some other revolutionary force, that accidentally caused huge losses when applying its ideology.  So there is certainly much depth to this game, on many levels, with no doubt many real world references tied in. e.g. ' Royce Bracket ' may be named for Winston W. Royce, computer scientist who coined the term 'software engineering'. ' Young Ladies ' perhaps a tip to Neal Stephenson cyberpunk novel ' The Diamond Age: Or, A Young Lady's Illustrated Primer '...? Talk of ' The Country ', a reference to Shakespeare's line: ' The undiscovered country from whose bourn, No traveller returns '...?  I don't feel that every single plot detail comes together in a perfectly defined way. Some things are deliberately left open to interpretation more than others, but I'm sure there will have been tweaks and compromises during development, interfering slightly with narrative sense. The mapping of game mechanics onto plot, while ever clever, and more thorough than most any other title, is not perfect. For example, the new game plus 'recursion' mode doesn't seem able to have a direct, causal, logically consistent plot mapping (however much you overthink it). Regardless, Transistor definitely has a rewardingly complex, detailed story. One that will bear re-examination after first completion. Recursion is ideal for this. It also lets you carry on to pick up second copies of each ability function, for even more extreme setups. I personally reached max level just before finishing my second run, then picked up the final, challenging (10 limiters) achievement within 30 minutes of starting a second recursion. Perfectly paced for 100%-ing the Steam achievements; very satisfying.  Value wise, it yielded about 40 hours of engaging play time for me. A large part of that was spent compulsively experimenting, as I like to do in such games (if they draw me in). This can be done in the context of regular combat, by simply restarting that section, back to your last access point where you can change things up again. But it is also the main utility of the sandbox, aside from trying to beat your highest single turn total damage figure (fun!). You reach this area via 'back doors' which crop up periodically in the main game. Also in this area are a whole bunch of differently structured tests and challenges, which pretty near double up the game's content and again encourage exploring and understanding the various functions: Time trials, escalating rounds of engagements to survive with a limited function set, etc. There are a half dozen logical puzzles that particularly tickled me, showing the flexibility of the turn() system. I wish there'd just been a   few   more... :-)

Story: 5/5 The storytelling to Transistor is told through the interactions between Red, the mute singer protagonist, and her weapon possessed by her lover as well as various messages on computers you find throughout the 5-hour campaign. Plenty of blanks are left for you to fill, and the ending, although a bit confusing, is extremely open to interpretation.  Visual: 5/5 The game looks like a painting that is gradually losing its colors. At the beginning everything is colorful and brushed with bright colors but as the game progresses colors become darker and by the end there is almost no bright color. This beautiful take on artstyle really adds to the mood of the story and its themes. The city of Cloudbank is a beautiful piece of art that you will want to learn about and explore.  Sound: 5/5 The soundtrack for this game is amazing, especially the songs with lyrics. Every song felt perfectly attached to the mood of what was going on in the story at the time of whatever exploring or fighting being done at the time. The voice acting is brilliant, especially the voice of Red's lover. Sound effects for your attacks and enemy attacks fit perfectly.  Gameplay: 4/5 The combat system takes a while to get used to due to a lack of handholding, but after the learning curve it's one-of-a-kind. Abilities are obtained that can be used to experiment with various combinations of equipping some abilities to others or using them as passive effects. At death instead of returning to the last check point immediately an ability is lost until 2 checkpoints later and health is restored to max, forcing you to use the abilities you have left in new innovative ways. Time can be slowed down to make strategic decisions on what abilities to use. Limiters can be used to add challenge to the game while allowing you to level up faster.   Replayability: N/A Will edit after I replay the game on its 'new game plus' that allows replay with past unlocked abilities.  Verdict: Transistor is an experience I have never had with any other game I have ever played. You will grow to care about the main characters, Cloudbank, and its inhabitants. The presentation value is extremely high with beautiful visuals, amazing sound design, and fantastic storytelling. The gameplay has a learning curve and can take getting used to, but once it clicks it's extremely addicting. Transistor is proof that video games can be art. If Transistor is on sale, you owe it to yourself to buy it.

I finished the game in eight hours, but by no means am I done with the game. Well into new game plus, I'm still experimenting with the gameplay, finding new combos. Let me explain the gameplay first.   You unlock 16 skills throughout the game. These 16 skills can be used as 4 primary skills, 4 passive skills, and each primary skill can get up to two skills 'supporting it' to alter or enhance the skill. Any skill obtained can be put in any of the slots, which allows for an endless array of customization. I'll try to sum up an example-- there's a dash skill. There's also a skill that pulls enemies to the user. So, I use that to support the dash skill. Enemies are now pulled to the location where I dash from. So, I summon a triggerable bomb before I dash. Enemies and the bomb are all drawn into the same location. I use another skill to detonate the bomb from a distance. Enemies drop.   There are many other combinations I haven't touched on, or even discovered. But there is a need to discover these kinds fo clever combos when the enemies get tougher-- and they do. Especially with optional limitiers enabled. These limiters increase damage enemies do, cause more to spawn, as well as a variety of other negative consequences. Never unfair, but always challenging. Think similar to those totems in Bastion.  As for the story-- it's really good. There's enough presented to you to have emotional affects on you, but there's a Dark Souls-esque deal with reading into the 'lore' of the game presented through paragraphs of information given to you from abilities, limiters, and etc. It works whether or not you read up on it, but you won't understand the full thing unless you read, most likely. The voiceacting has no flaws that I can call out, every voice-actor is superb. Especially Royce and the narrator. (Which are really half of the game's voice actors, but still.)   The music? It's good. A little subtle most times, I only found myself openly digging the music during combat during an early bossfight, otherwise the music was relatively in the background. However, the more I use limiters that cause battles to become more hectic, the more I notice intense music. Still, it could've been more prominent.   Overall, it's an amazing game. Completely worth the price. Again, I finished the game in eight hours. But there's more to do in the new game plus mode. Enemy spawn locations and patterns are random, there's new elements to the story, and so on.   It's a great game overall, and I see myself putting much more time into it.

First I would just like to say DID enjoy this game, and it has many positive aspects that I would like to point out. Transistor, first off, is wonderfully sculpted with beautiful art and music, and mechanics that are easy to handle. Most of the game was surrounded in mystery, and you learn more about the characters as you go along.   The game focuses on fighting enemies to try and reach the next part of an area. It has many of the same mechanics as The Bastion, another game by Supergiant, featuring a birds eye view with a similar landscape layout.  I especially love the fighting sequence which is something that I've never seen before in a game, whereas you can pause the battle plan out your moves which are then executed after you are ready. You have several attacks you can use, which take different ammounts of your energy during planning depending on how powerful it is.   Though this way of battle has its merits, it is a bit too powerful and players will most likely become quickly dependant on it. When the player is deprived of it, they are usually exceptionally weak and fall quickly. However, once you have a lot of powerful skills, by the time you are in a situation that you are momentarily no longer able to plan, the enemies are down to small numbers and are quickly defeated.   This game is actually a little too dependant on this kind of battle. Once players are deprived of planning, they are most likely to resort to running away and using repetitive attacks until their planning abillity returns.  One bad aspect is that the storyline is a bit challenging to decipher. Sure, there are guides on Steam to the plot, but it is hard to enjoy the game if you cannot understand the plot while playing it. The game is pretty linear anyway, and the plot is very unnecessary to the game as you would end up going the same way because there is simply no other way to go. The storyline becomes obsolete and players will most likely find it uninteresting as it contributes very little to the actual gameplay.  All in all I would say Transistor is a good concept of a game, but it was quite short and players will basically only care about getting to the end of the stage, rather than the story. I would like to see games with these sort of mechanics in the future though, such as the battle format and the design. If another game was made like this, but with a more complicated and longer plot, and a little more insentive to get to the end of the stage rather than to just get there, it would be worthy of a more positive review. I finished this game in two days, and am only slightly impressed by reasons I have already discussed. So if you are reading this review, try the game out for yourself to see if it is actually meritable. I assume it's probably a different experience for everybody.

Most of the reviews here are trash so far. I'm only a little over an hour into the game, but I just want to say that Supergiant Games has really stepped up their game (hoho) with Transistor.   Yet again featuring Logan Cunningham as the narrator of sorts, Transistor exists in its own different universe. The aesthetic appeal of the game will grab you instantly, with hand-painted graphics, fantastic visual effects, and wonderful soundtrack. So many little unnecessary but definitely appreciated features have been put into the game as well, giving it an extra layer of polish.  The gameplay is its own beast, and it has been done exceedingly well, allowing the player to shift between realtime fighting and strategic combat at the whim of the player. It feels completely different from Bastion, regardless of the fact that the two games have similar presentation and graphical style.  There are some bugs right now (some of which are game breaking for certain setups), but these will surely be fixed within the next few hours or days. I'll update my review when I'm finshed.

If you played Bastion (and who hasn't at this point?) then you'll immediately see that this game is an improvement on the formula. You've got old friends from Bastion returning, including a beautiful art style, the music of Darren Korb and narration from Logan Cunningham, limiters to add some extra challenge (like Bastion's idols), and a variety of weapons and skills. Now, on top of that, you now have more strategic and challenging combat, more varied levels and environments, and a wider variety of enemy types.  It probably won't win over anyone who wasn't a fan of Bastion, but for those who enjoyed it it's both more and better.

The game doesn't make an effort to give you any context or try to engage and invest you into the story or characters. I want to start by saying that if you are a hardcore fan of Bastion (Like me), then I absolutely recommend playing Transistor. However if you have never played Bastion, or for whatever reason didn't like it, then this is NOT the game for you.   I expected a lot from this game, being from the same maker from Bastion, and for the most part I wasn't let down. The one problem with this game is the combat, which almost ruins this game entirely.  Combat is completely based on abilities you use. You gain various abilities as you progress, but there are no basic attacks. Meaning the combat revolves around these abilities or 'Functions' as the game calls them. With the new combat system known as 'Turn' players can stop time and maneuver the around the fight planning what moves to make. I would relate it to V.A.T.S in the Fallout games, but much more in depth. Each move comsumes a part of your 'Turn bar'. When the bar is empty you can no longer make a move. In theory this is a great idea for a game and I was all for it in the beginning. The problem with Turn however is that a function like this should be up to the players choice in games, but with the amount of damage enemies do and the time it takes for you to cast a single ability, it is almost impossible to finish a fight sequence without relying completely on it. Now one would think you could solve this problem by just turning down the diffuculty. Unfortunately you the difficulty is set, and cannot be changed. To make matters worse once you have used turn it goes on cooldown (based on how much of the turn bar you consumed), making all of your ability unusable until turn is usable again. There is an ability in the game that can be used during turn's cooldown, and it can be applied to other abilities as well, but once again with the long cast animations and the amount of damage enemies do, it is much wiser to simply run away and wait for Turn to come off cooldown. This makes the game have very little veriety since you have to rely completely on a single function. Turn should be giving the player a viable option to change the flow of combat and not completely dictate it.  However the ONLY problem I have with Transistor is the combat. The rest of the game is absolutely fantastic. The soundtrack is absolutely beautiful, the visuals are just stunning, the story is a little hard to follow but is interesting nonetheless, and the narration is even better than before. All of these combined are enough for me to look past the problems with the combat and continue playing.  I was expecting a game that would rival Bastion. What i got was a game that can never hope to come near Bastion's level. In the end it didnt meet expectations, but is still an acceptable game.

I decided I would write a review specifically about Transistor's similarities to Bastion and what it does better and worse.  Combat: Both games feature incredibly customizable combat. Bastion has around 10 different weapon, which can all be upgraded, and you can have two with you at a time for combos such as all melee, all range, mix, all fast, all slow, etc etc. Transistor gives you four slots for attacks, starting you off with a weak fast attack, a slow strong attack, a dash, and area of effect. However, it quickly becomes more than that. The amount of combat customization is staggering, you get a hefty amount of moves. BUT then very single move can be used as one of up to four passive abilities AND can be used to modify your current active moves. The customization takes it a step up above Bastions already impressive amount.  As far as the systems go. Bastion was very much action oriented, The Kid has a dedicated Roll and Block button and the combat is that of an action game. However, it's much harder to draw similarities to transistors gameplay. It's much more tactical, you have the ability to go into a 'planning' mode where time stops, and you can take as long as you want to choreograph a set of actions for the protagonist, Red, which she will then execute very quickly while the enemies must sit there and take it. After planning mode is finished and your moves executed, the meter must recharge before Red can do this again, leaving her vulnerable. She has no dedicated block or dodge, anything resembling these abilities must be achieved through the loadout you pick, leaving her vulnerable and her only option to find cover behind the protruding blocks on the ground, which can be destroyed by either you or enemy fire (they will regenerate.) However, while planning mode leaves you vulnerable, the ability to quickly execute moves makes it a must, activating abilities in real time alone isn't going to cut it. It's tough to get the hang of it, but once you find a build that works for you, and get a full grasp on how to best utilize the mechanics, that combat can be incredibly fun. Some may prefer the action combat of Bastion, some may prefer Transistors strategic approach, this will come down to personal tastes, however, Transistors combat mechanics are structurally in-depth and interesting, if they click with you I believe you will have loads of fun.   Death in Bastion also has less long term affects. You run out of potions? Back to The Bastion with you. Transistor is interesting because what happens is when you run out of health your active more that uses the most power breaks, and remains broken for two savepoints. This is quite a bit more interesting as the penalty for running out of health is that you have to temporarily change up your strategy. Which is quite a bit more interesting than a game over. I do not know what happens once all four of your powers are gone. I assume once that happens you do experience a game over situation.  Enemy variety is a bit down from Bastion. However the actually variety in function of the enemies is up. This is likely because of the more tactical aspect of the game. The enemies can come together in a perfect harmony that will make you really need to think about how you are going to approach a situation, and they can really keep the pressure on. Another thing worth noting is the enemies level up with you, so as you progress enemies you've been seeing since your first encounter in the game will continue to stay as threatening as ever.   Fans of Bastion also might remember praying to the gods to impose more challenge on the game in return for rewards. This happens as well in Transistor, however, it is mandatory. Occasionally when you level up, you are essentially given a choice as to how the game will get harder for you, with each option also having a corresponding reward. This system is very cool, however this does mean you cannot pile all of these challenges on at will like you can in Bastion, which some may not like. Overall though there almost two different uses of a similar system. Bastion is essentially turning on hardcore mode within the worlds lore for some rewards. Where Transistor is essentially saying 'Ok, the game is gonna get harder now, but you get a choice in how that happens.' Another nice thing is the rewards are all just unlock slots for your customizable build, and the none of the challenges are expressly harder so which choice is the most desrable all comes down to you. Causing you run into interesting situation where there slot you want might make the game harder in a way you find especially difficult.  Overall, the combat's level of customization is staggering, from a technical standpoint Transistor is quite a bit more in-depth.  The hub world: This is probably the only area where Transistor falls flat. They decided to include a hub world. In Bastion, The Bastion is where you deal with a lot of your upgrades, as well as getting little tidbits of the worlds lore, and selecting which level you would like to go to (including challenge levels). In Transistor all of those things, including the lore tidbits, are dealt with via leveling up, and the terminals you run into throughout the game which also work as save points (there is no level system). From a gameplay standpoint, the only reason this hub exists is for the challenge courses. You also cannot visit it whenever you'd like, doors to this, as I recall, unnamed place appear throughout your game, you will not know when. Because of this going there essentially becomes a pain. Where as in Bastion it just happened. Making any of the content there less appealing. I would rather have accesed the challenge courses from the terminal I access everything else in. There is also seemingly some things to do, a hammock to lie in, a ball to bounce, I ended up with a tamed version of one of the enemies. But I don't really know for certain because by half way through the game I stopped even going in when I saw a door open for it. Short and simple, it was a neat little area, it didn't need to exist, or it should have been easier to access. However, this is the only time where the design of the game feels anything short of well thought out and smart. The game would have lasted longer for me if it wasn't a chore to get to the bonus content. This also brings me to my next point.  Game length: I beat the game at around 3.8-3.9 hours of playtime, a bit under what seems to be the average of 5. Don't get me wrong, it was a damn good 3.8 hours I don't regret. But there was easily the possibility for two other bosses, two at the least maybe even three, that would not have detracted from the experience if they existed the game even sort of lead me to believe I would encounter. Bastion's playtime was also longer because it invited me to experience it's extra content, whereas Transistor made me go out of my way to find it. Which is why I ended up skipping it largely.  Artistic design stuff: This is largely subjective so I'll be brief and just mention some changes people might want to be aware of.  The voice of Rucks, Logan Cunningham, returns. This had me worried that Transistor would be 'Bastion but different' but he is not a narrator this time, and he is actually using a (somewhat) different voice. His role feels different enough from his role as Rucks that the game doesn't feel like 'Bastion but this time x is different'. Some may also find him less 'intrusive' this time although I doubt anyone who liked the amount he appeared in Bastion will find him particularly 'absent' comparatively. Artstyle is kinda similar but different enough, it's nice seeing a cohesive world in this style and I'm sure plenty of people will be glad to find you cannot fall off the edge of the world this time. Transistor is the second game of Supergiant Games, a small independent developer known for Bastion. Transistor follows in its footsteps with its gorgeous visuals and beautiful music, which is again matched to the story of the game. The story is based around Red, a singer who lost her voice, and the Transistor, some sort of high-tech cyberpunk sword which also can talk. Its used as primary weapon and can also “absorb” the essence of deceased persons, which unlocks new abilities, here called functions. They can be used in four active slots, as modifiers or in up to four passive slots. Every function can be used in any type of slot with varying effects, using them in different slots unlocks new lore to read about the persons symbolized by the function. Experimentation is key, as the game does not hold your hand but encourages to change the skill set around to find effect combinations. Combat can be done in real-time and with a pause mode, called turn(). In turn(), skills can be chained together and are then executed in super speed. But the game does progress, even slightly, which sometimes can the damage predictions shown in turn() render moot. The system takes some getting used to, but ones mastered is very effective and unique, although some say it is similar to the combat used in the Fallout series, which I haven't played (yet). The story is again a part of the game. It takes place in the city of Cloudbank, which has a very unique art deco cyberpunk setting, where an AI only know as “the process” has gotten out of control. The Transistor is a key component in battling it, but I'm not giving away anything more. Logan Cunningham is back, this time as the voice of the Transistor with is signature cowboy-style voice. But this time more characters speak (except for the Protagonist) which have equally unique, but very skilled and fitting voice actors. The game is a very unique experience, the visuals and music alone make it a masterpiece, not even considering the well crafted story. Compared to Bastion, it adds a combat system that needs some getting used to, but is very rewarding.  Also: If you got friends/family/etc. that don't think games can be art, show them Transistor. If this game does not convince them, probably nothing will.

I did not enjoy this game. I was so looking forward to it, but it was a disappointment. Even if I cannot convince you that you should not buy this game, at least this review may lower your expectations in a good way.  First off, I must concede that the art is lovely and I enjoyed the music in the game. Everything else was problematic.  Obtuse  The plot moves very slowly, keeping the mystery until pretty much at the end, but the final reveal does not explain or justify the events of the game.  The in-game UI is overwhelming when you first get to use it. The attack and moding system is not obvious, and the UI does nothing to help explain how abilities works or how to configure them. Even worse, they use a lot of contemporary computer terms but with different meanings, so their terminology can be disorienting. There are a couple of times early in the game that force the UI open and require you to fiddle with stuff before you can continue, but they don't explain what you have to do.  I need to explain a core combat feature before my critique will make sense. The main character has two modes of fighting: real-time and pre-planned. In the real-time combat, your character is at an extreme disadvantage. Enemies move faster than you, have greater reach than you, and they definitely overwhelm you with numbers. Most of your attacks have a short range. In the pre-planned combat system, you pause the action and plan out one or a series of attacks. After the plan is activated, it is carried out automatically in real-time, but your character moves much faster to let you accomplish things that you couldn't in real-time. Also, all of your attacks do more damage in pre-planned combat and/or activate new combined effects.  Pre-planned combat is clearly superior to real-time, so the game limits it. Each action or movement in the pre-planned system uses up resources on a special meter that refills over time when you are back to the real-time. If you don't have enough of the special meter, then you cannot pause time or use the pre-planned combat. This is where you get into trouble.  Planning combat attacks when combat is paused gives you feedback about how much damage each attack will do and whether it will be enough to eliminate an enemy, yet it is often wrong. Enemies that choose to teleport themselves after being hit, bounce a random direction, or activate a defense are not reflected in the combat planning phase, so it is very easy to commit yourself to a big attack that uses up all of your special meter (leaving you defenseless for a period of time) which would have been OK if the enemies that you had planned to be defeated were defeated, but instead you end up dangerously close to enemies who punish you for believing the UI feedback.  Trolling  One of the main features of the game is a large selection of acquired abilities that can be used as either attacks or as modifiers for other attacks. A big part of the user experience is mixing and matching of these abilities to find combinations you enjoy.  When fighting, if your health bar goes down to 0, instead of ending the fight, the game randomly removes one of your abilities and resets your health bar. If it goes down to 0 again, then you lose another ability, and so on until you lose your last ability and are forced to reset the fight from the beginning with all of your abilities restored.  If you survive a fight with abilities lost, then they stay lost until you can explore your way to the next single-use restore terminal. The game is extremely linear, so usually you can't backtrack and use a previously-skipped restore terminal. It may require you to limp along with fewer (or less preferable) abilities for several fights before you can get your abilities back.  At first, I thought this was an innovative way to force you to mix and match your abilities after fights, but very quickly I realized that this is just the game devs trolling you. Although every ability can be either an attack or a modifier to an attack, I found that many of them were useful only in a carefully balanced loadout of attacks and mods. The removal of a single random ability often cripples an entire loadout, and after combat there may not be a way to rearrange the remaining abilities into a useful combination.  The better option in most fights where you lose even a single ability is to let the game completely kill you. If you lose all of your abilities, then the fight resets to your previous state. So you either finish a fight with abilities missing and hate your new restrictions, or you just stand still and let the enemies hit you over and over again until you can restart the fight fresh. Neither option is fun.  An alternative would be to never allow yourself to lose an ability in the first place, but the game loves to give new enemies traits that you have never seen before and old enemies traits that they didn't have before, so I found myself constantly confused why my attacks didn't work and how enemies were doing things I had never seen before. These changes are made without any feedback or forewarning, resulting in lots of cheap deaths (or ability loss in this case). Variety is a good thing, but in a game where your character is so vulnerable unless you use your limited, time-stopping special ability, it is critical that you can accurately plan your attacks, and yet the planning system is inaccurate and intentionally hides information to misguide you.  Another way that I was tricked into overcommitting myself was when the game started adding multiple health bars to bosses. Normal enemies only have a single health bar, so after hours of re-enforcing that system, the game started adding multiple health bars to certain bosses. There's no tell that I could discover to know how many health bars an enemy has. This led me to commit all of my special meter into an attack that the planning system told me would defeat them, but instead left me standing right next to the very-much-not-defeated boss and unable to do anything for a period of time (long enough for me to lose another ability from the barrage of boss attacks).  Poor Pacing  I already mentioned the bad plot pacing above, but there are other pacing issues with the game.  This game has a narrator, like in the developer's previous game, Bastion. In Bastion, the narrator comments on what the main character does in present tense. It was a fresh idea, and got lots of praise. The developers must have felt that their next game needed to have a narrator too, but they really didn't know what to do with him.  In Transistor, the narrator really has nothing useful to say. The narrator doesn't comment on what's going on, but rather fills in a little history. If any of that history was entertaining, then it might have been worth having, but I did not enjoy it. The devs even created multiple, un-skippable sequences that show the main character riding a motorcycle for long periods of time with no gameplay just so that they could have a situation where the narrator could talk, and yet he had nothing interesting to say.  There are puzzles in the game, which could have been a great way to change the pace from the extremely linear exploration and frequent combat, but there were not enough of them to help the pacing much, and the mechanics of the puzzles blended into the environment art so well that I found them more confusing than anything else.  Buggy  At least a couple of times I got my character stuck outside the playable space and had to reload the game.  Conclusion  Great art and music. Everything else is a mess.

As a game studio, when your first game is something as good as Bastion, it's a tough act to follow. And as a player, it's also tough to not constantly compare the two games, even if Transistor is not a sequel to Bastion. Unfortunately, that comparison only highlights the weaknesses of Transistor, which might be a decent game, but is severely below Bastion.  The greatest part of Transistor is the story. I think the game shouldn't have started 'in media res', because it makes for a confusing beginning, but once you start to get all the pieces of the puzzle, it all makes sense and paints an interesting picture. The world of Cloudbank is only hinted at, but it's an interesting, original world with interesting characters.  However, it's a bit of a shame we mostly learn about theses people and that world through archive files, and that we have to go through a completely empty environment. For story-reasons that i will not spoil, the world of Transistor is empty. You will almost never encounter any life, only enemies. Bastion's world was a post-apocalyptic world, and yet, it was teeming with traces of past life, and also new forms of life. It was also very varied, with each level having it's own distinct feel and color scheme. In Transistor, every environment is a flat expense in the middle of the city, and all the levels look the same. Moreover though there are reasons that it's deserted, it's weird that you find absolutely no traces of previous life, or even a lone survivor to talk to.  The fact that you won't meet anyone also creates another problem : the only 'person' that your character, Red, meets, is her sword. At the beginning of the game, you grab the sword that was used to kill someone...and that someone has been absorbed by the sword, and is able to talk to you. I will not spoil who that person is, but he is gonna help Red survives her ordeal. However, Red lost her voice, and thus, the sword is the only one able to talk...and boy, he does talk a lot. The only voice you hear, offering advices, opinions, etc. He is supposed to be a friend, but since he is the only one talking constantly, and giving you advices constantly, it soon feels like he is just bossing you around. 'Go there, do that, etc.'. An endless monologue, that is supposed to both guide the players, and help Red, and tell the story of the world...by being all that it just fails at everything, after a while that voice gets way too irksome, and you just want him to shut up.  But enough with the atmosphere, and let's talk about the gameplay. Supergiant Games have created an original combat system. The game plays in real time, with an isometric view like Bastion offered. However, at any point, you have the possibility of stopping time. When you do it, it starts a 'turn', with a tactical UI. Here you can plan your next actions as much as you want. Experiment with movements, attacks, and see the results. The only limit is the 'turn bar', which depletes with each move or attack. Once you're satisfied with your plan, you go out of the tactical view, and all your actions executes as you wanted, while the rest of the game is almost stopped (it's not a total pause, but it's very close to). This gives you a tremendous advantage against your opponents, who only works in real time. However, once your action are done, you're not able to use turn until your 'turn bar' is filled up again (which takes about 5s if you used all of it). Also, most of your attacks are disabled while the turn bar is filling up, which makes you very vulnerable. That makes for a different flow of combat that we're used and it's interesting to try it.  This turns system is greatly enhanced by the 'function' system of your sword. Your sword isn't a classic weapon. It has 'functions', which you gain every time you level up. Most of them are for damage (such as Breach() which throws an arrow piercing enemies) but a few are purely for support like 'convert an enemy to your side' or 'weaken an enemy'. You can only have 4 functions active at a time, but you can upgrade one function with up to two others, which will greatly change their effect. For example, you can have a function that damage and weaken an enemy at the same time and also makes you invisible for a few seconds. You can also equip up to 4 functions as global upgrades, which mean you're able to use up to 16 functions at the same time (4 attacks, upgraded with 2 functions each, and 4 global upgrades). On the whole, that function system is a great idea, because it allows you to customize your playstyle as you sit fit, and enhances the planning aspect of the game.  So, a new tactical turn system + a very customizable attack system should make for great combat, right ? Well, it should, if the enemies were up to par. Unfortunately, that's where it completely falls apart. At the beginning of the game it feels like there are many enemies, each with their own role and way to screw you. However, the more you progress in the game, the more you will understand that they have the same strengths and weaknesses. Which mean that once you've found a function combo that works well, there is little incentive to switch to something else. The more levels and functions you gain, the more refined your ultimate combo will be, and the less incentive you will have to switch things up.  If you're a tactical-minded player, it shouldn't be hard for you to find a great combo, and then spam it over and over again. There is none of the complexity of others tactical games, such as Tactical RPGs or western turn-based games. This is even more visible during the NewGame+, where enemies are totally unable to provide a challenge to your levelled up character. NewGame+ even randomizes the enemies, meaning they are even less tactically organized than they used to. Not that you care...every enemy is the same, a fodder for your unique combo.  The game actually disincentive to try to switch things up. Bastion offered 10 idols that added 10 optional handicaps with greater rewards, to make it harder and more interesting for players who like being challenged. It really tasked you to get the most ouf of your weapons and really becomes better at the game. Transistor has a similar system, the 'Limiters', but it fails to be as interesting as the idols. In truth, most of theses limiters are barely noticeable. I've been playing my NewGame+ with all 10 limiters, and barely feels the effect of them because I'm cruising through with my unique combo. However, one of them actually penalizes you for switching your functions in and out, which mean that if you have a combo that works, it's better to keep using it, than try playing with the function system.  So the conclusion is unavoidable: When you're spamming the same combo over and over again, against enemies that feel the same, that can have only one issue : boredom. And that's definitely how i felt. There were a lot of times when i was playing and then after a while i was thinking 'i don't want to keep at it', and just stopped playing. I forced myself to go through the game to be able to see the end of the wonderful story. And then i forced myself through NewGame+ to be sure i wasn't missing anything, and unfortunately, the more i played, the more i noticed the game's weaknesses.   A great story with interesting characters can't save all by themselves a weak gameplay, especially since the irksome companion also fails to be as compelling as Bastion's narrator was.

Transistor. Ever since I finished Transistor I have been in two minds about it and frankly I cannot make it up. Visually the world is stunning, the soundtrack marvelous, the story is interesting and the combat is both entertaining and interesting. When I reached the end however, I didn't quite believe it. All I could think is 'Where is the rest?' Frankly, the game was great, but then it ended out of nowhere, and I was not happy with the abrupt and unsatisfying finish. I don't mind a short game at all, but I just cannot quite grasp that it should have ended there, when it felt like I was only getting deeper into the story. There was no wow moment, no satisfying conclusion or memorable final encounter. It just ended, and I was upset in a bad way. It pains me to not recommend Transistor, when it was executed it was beautiful, but ultimately the experience wasn't worth it. All I can say is it was like Bastion again with a different setting, soundtrack and combat changes, but disapointing. The soundtrack I will take with me, but nothing more than a rather painful parting to say I don't recommend this game. If you want something mostly similar, but satisfying to the last second, I thoroughly recommend Bastion. I'm sorry Supergiant.

Having loved Bastion, i so wanted to like this... but i can't. There's no charm whatsoever, and the story is indecipherably delivered in an absurdly non-user friendly system. The character voice accompanying you is as flavorful and soulful as listening to a drunken oaf constantly jammer on about nothing of value...  The good sides can be summarized quickly; the art style is pretty fantastic, the music is overall good if a bit spotty in places, and the way skills interreact with eachother can give some very interesting results... even if they feel overtly sanitized.   The bad sides are... not so easy to talk about.  The way you figure out the story in the game is not by gameplay. Every character you meet (dead or about to be as they are) leave behind skills for you. These skills can be slotted in 3 manners; 1, As an actual usable skill 2. Augmenting another 3. As a passive. To unlock the story, every skill you get must be once planted in one of these slots for a minimum duration of one combat where the skill must be used. The way the story is delivered to you is a couple of paragraphs of plaintext with some uninteresting and unenlightening comments given by the voiceactor. This would be fine and understandable if the game were like Baldur's Gate, where you expect to ponder on choices and actually react to dialogue... this is as interesting way to deliver a story as reading a random fanfiction about something you are inherently assumed to care about, even if you're told pretty much nothing of it.  The combat is... an incredibly dull blend of active and turn-based in the same vein, if worse, that Fallout 3/New Vegas VATS system screwed things up. It's difficult to explain, but i'll try: You can use your skills in real time, they have short cooldowns and differing amount of animation times to use them. However, you pretty much never will, because there's an alternative... ultimately more boring method to fight, which is required of you in most fights, (as you have no other way of dodging enemy attacks) the turn-based system. The turn system practically freezes time for you, allows you to do a set number of actions, including movement, until a certain amount of time is used up, after which your character will perform the actions automatically in pseudo-freeze time. This system trivializes any and all difficulty in the game, and yet it is absolutely necessary that you utilize it.  After you've used the turn system, you wait for it to recharge for a few seconds in real time, and just so happens, pretty much every skill you have will be on cooldown during this time... so you can't have any kind of fun during waiting it to come back, unless you consider hiding behind breakable walls and just casually walking (running not allowed) away from enemies.  There are also spikes in difficulty, but even with a vast amount of things that are supposed to make the game more difficult (They really don't, such as needing an arbitrary additional hit before you can collect the capsule that makes an enemy respawn is not about difficulty, it's about tedium), the game is overall non-challenging to likely anyone. 'Spikes in Difficulty' just means you walk away slightly further from your enemies. The combat feels sluggish, there's no adrenaline rush for achieving anything, and it all feels like a big chore.  The game also keeps crashing both itself and steam, because for some reason they're using a really poorly coded version of Demon's/Dark souls type system where you see blurry phantoms of other players roaming about. If there's any sort of a hitch in the system, the game freezes up and crashes Steam with it... and there's nothing you can do about it, outside of doing it in offline mode, and this game certainly is not worth that much effort. --- Ultimately it's a hugely disappointing experience for me.  As an aside: I should know well better to buy titles from indie devs that hit it big only once before, as personally, Arcen had already burnt me violently on that regard. Having loved AI War, the abysmal A Valley Without Wind deserves nothing but scorn. This isn't as bad, comparatively, but considering how unconditionally Bastion was loved... it's not a far off deal.

Its kind of like the V.A.T.S system from Fallout where you can play in real time, but you can also stop time and plan out moves. Each has pros and cons, real time allows you to spam attacks without cooldown, but if you use the stop time mechanic Turn(), you can plan out moves for maximum damage, but afterwards you are not able to use your Functions till Turn() recharges. Its a very fun system, and one that has a lot of replayability for a few more playthroughs. One of my favorite parts of the game is that nothing is spoon fed to you. You figure out the story and what happened to the city of Cloudbank through expositon from terminals you find through out the game. Even your Functions contribute to the story, with each Function being the soul of dead citizen that the titular sword absorbed. Anyhow, I got carried away. This game is a work of art, nothing less of a masterpeice. Go and buy it. It is a bit on the short side, though I wouldn't really know since I didn't beat it yet. Transistor really is a brilliant spark of genius from Supergiant Games (an independent company, mind you) in which they have painted a breathtaking RPG experience that transcends the conventional frameworks of meaningless grinding, cliché professions, and 'skills' that rely on spamming keys whenever possible. The gameplay is heavily dependent on tactics and strategies, but the game itself guides the players to easily grasp the concepts to really shine through by utilizing a dash of planning skills.  On a different note (pardon the pun), the music is sublime from each scene-to-scene, and aurally stimulating as the play styles switch back and forth. The electronica genre of the soundscape in its entirety really befits the aesthetically vivid and stark future-esque art of the game without being 'done too much' or juxtaposed in any way. The female vocal line that weaves in and out of the songs really brings-out Red's story and personality even when she... has nothing to say. The soundtracks are truly captivating - and as a music major, I don't say this lightly!  The art, too, is very stunning. The cutscenes are rich in vibrant colors and are drawn (painted) to seem as they were done with a dry-brush. They are highly stylized, chic, and tell a lot more than an average 3D CGI HD 60FPS over-the-top animation can. Seriously, you don't need a lot of motions and actions to make a scene seem interesting. Ever read a beautifully-drawn comic book before? That's pretty much how it feels to watch these cutscenes.  Finally, what would the music and art be without a great story to support? Well, they'll still be good music and art... but the story is ALSO good, I assure you! It has a pungent aroma of a modern-noir. To list a few, it has a femme fatale protagonist, an organized group of criminals as your antagonists, dangerous alleyways, cityscapes, and it's even topped with the quintessential 'I have to gather more clues to figure out what's really going on' theme that exists in almost all noir fictions. However, in the midst of all these elements, the creators have planted a painfully obvious yet mild romance that continues to blossom between the star-crossed protagonists. Well, what would a good noir fiction BE without a little bit of romance, huh?  Overall, I believe Transistor will be a great addition to anyone who enjoys games with highly aesthetic qualities (BOTH in music and in art), a well-written story, and a rather unique playing style. If ANYTHING, this game is like an interactive comic book that's definitely 'worth reading' even as a casual reader. ...You know what I mean.  All in all, I give thumbs-up to Supergiant Games for concocting this gorgeous game and I hope to see more creations from them soon!

Transistor's an odd sort of game. If one was to analytically break down its components, one would be hard pressed to find anything that is perhaps truly innovative. Certianly it lends a lot to Supergiant's last game, Bastion (another excellent game. Spoiler there? Oh well...), but Bastion's strenght wasn't in innovation, really.  Transistor's strength lies in its excecution, in smoothness of purpose and design. Of doing what it does not with originality of gameplay, but doing it WELL. One does not simply walk through a series of rooms, idly connected to create a singular pathway. One is traversing a city, and there is no doubt that you are. The enemies start out simple and have such basic 'gimicks', but they soon not only gain new ones, but start to have wonderful and frustrating synergy at the same time.   Even the concept of new abilities really has nothing 'new' per se, but dovetails neatly together in such interesting ways. A single ability can either be used as a primary attack technique, or it can provide an enhancement to another technique, OR it can provide an overall passive bonus. Simple, yes? And yet both elegant and effective: A single new technique suddenly opens up all manner of new tactics.  Did I mention the music? If there's one thing that Supergiant seems to have locked down more than anything, it's soundtrack, and it shows in spades here. The songs fit the ambiance of the levels, adding that little extra to mood, and frankly they dammed well stand on their own, without even a game to be set to them.  Are other games 'more innovative'? Probably. Are they 'Newer, with sharper more realistic graphics?' I suppose.   Do those games let you sit back at the end of a session and just marvel at what you've seen and done and heard, and think 'That was Beautiful'? I don't think so.  Don't cheat yourself. Don't watch a playthrough, don't watch spoilers. Get the game, and experience it.

From the makers of bastion comes transistor, a short but unique experience of action and turn based rpg combined into one package. I love bastion and I have looked forward to this game for awhile. My first impression is the game feels like bastion right away because of the voice accompanying you throughout the game and also the artstyle certainly resembles bastion's as well. The strongest aspect of the game is definitely the atmosphere and the story for me. They are unlike any other games I have seen in a long while.   I do not want to spoil the story much, but basically you play as Red, a singer and her boyfriend, a talking sword. You are on a journey to uncover strange happenings around town. The story focuses on a slightly dark scifi theme and a love theme on the side with a dash of light humor. There is somewhat a typical save the world scenario but it is not cliched that much, and I still enjoy the unpredictability up until the very end.   The music sounds contemporary which you might find intriguing. However for me, they do no evoke much emotions, only slight admiration from me. But they suit the game's atmosphere very well! You can unlock the music player by completing tests, similar to dreams in bastion.   Controls feel abit awkward at first because the game does not really explain them well at first. But once you get used to it, it is not bad at all. You will do fine with mouse and keyboard without a gamepad or joystick. The controls are quite similar to your standard MMO. 4 active skillslots assigned to 1 to 4, and use your mouse to move. There are alternative ways to do it, but i think that is the way to go.   The gameplay feels a little weak compared to bastion simply because it feels like it is caught between action and turn based. Aside from being a standard action rpg like bastion, here you have the option to freeze the game and take all day to decide your next moves while your enemy stands waiting. However, using this option will disable most of your skills for a certain period of time after you finish, leaving you vulnerable (can be bypassed with skill setup). This feature is optional to use throughout the game and you can finish the game without it, with the exception of the final battle. The beauty here is that you can tailor your skill build to suit your playing style, similar to bastion. Want to play it like a turn based rpg or action rpg? Tune your skills to suit your playing style. Personally I chose to play it like a normal action rpg instead of turn based intuitively, and sorry to say bastion is better here. I think this game is better played turn based style, where you can experiment with alot of different combos. Or you can certainly do both!   You can increase the difficulty of the game according to your taste just like bastion. Except they call it limiters here and you gain bonus xp as the difficulty increases.  The replayability is low because the game is very short and does not have any sidequests other than the tests, similar to the dreams in bastion. You can play the game from the beginning again carrying over your level and skills. The enemy levels up as you do this time. THe maximum level is 30 and easily achieved on the 2nd playthrough if you keep the difficulty high. What is also missing is the scoring system, which also lowers replayability.   Overall this game is short because it is meant to be a low budget game, with minimal to no animation during the story cutscenes and minimal content. However the game is worth your money because even though it is a short game, it is a good one and thus worth experiencing.

Transistor has much in common with Bastion - the game made a few years back by the same studio (Supergiant Games). But at the same time Transistor is very different and it takes all the Bastion's best feats to the whole new level.  There are two main gameplay improvements: the Turn, and the Functions.  The Turn is a kind of tactical pause during which you may plan several moves. These moves are almost instantly performed when you unpause. Then you run around and try to avoid enemy fire while the Turn cools down. So, in fact, game's mostly about tactical planning.  The Functions are a sort of replacement for weapons and skills. Every Function represents a soul of a certain VIP of the Transistor world. When you use a certain Function, you get some info about the person this Function/soul used to belong to. It's also important that you may combine Functions. Each of them may be installed as a Passive Bonus, an Action or an Action Bonus. And each Function has different effects in all of those three possible roles.  I also was impressed how the same voice actor Logan Cunningham sounded different and new. While in Bastion he was more of a cowboy by the bonfire, in Transistor he sounds more as an old friend in a very unfriendly city.  The city itself is great and atmopsheric. It reminds me of Bioshock, Shadowrun and No One Lives Forever at the same time.

If you loved the art direction and storytelling in Bastion, you'll love Transistor. A surprising point was the brilliant soundtrack which I urge you to pay attention to while playing.  The combat and function system is diverse and customizable and gets deeper the more you unlock,

Holy crap, Supergiant Games really outdid themselves with this one. I was a huge Bastion fanboy from the get-go due to its unique atmosphere and its fusion of gameplay mechanics and story flavor. Combined with the fact that Supergiant is a tiny studio holding its weight against the massive giants in the industry, I was eagerly rooting for Transistor. It completely exceeded my expectations and is hands down my favorite game of all time. The gameplay itself is nuanced and is built off of one of the most interesting upgrade systems I've seen to date; instead of upgrading stats, you unlock functions that can be used as an active ability, a modifier to another active, or as a constant passive boost. This leads to an absurd number of combinations, each of which have value in different situations. The story itself is jam-packed with feels and left hooks. I won't give too much away, but suffice to say it definitely turns the standard 'see antagonist group, fight antagonists one by one' formula way on its head. Darren Korb (the audio director at Supergiant) definitely upped his game on this one, so I highly recommend picking up the OST along with it. Can't recommend this game enough.

Supergiant games has struck lighting again with their latest entry in to the action Rpg genre, Transistor.  The makers of Bastion brings you to the cyberpunk city of Cloudbank, a city despite its color and flare, has a few things going on. The main character, and the character you control throughout your adventure, Red, is a songstress that has a bit of a rough night, from dealing with an assassination attempt on her life, to losing her voice, and is now in possession of a weapon which now contains the data of the person who helped her narrowly escape. Both of you wade through the city, fighting a group of mechanical creatures called the process, who has taken over the city in the meantime. It all adds up to an action filled journey as you try to seek retribution for the attempt on Reds life, and the connection between the process and the transistor.  The story also isn't told in a conventional sense, as from the very start of the game you are thrown into the middle of a situation and left to figure things out on your own. You could probably complete the game a couple of times and still not understand everything around you. The only narration is through the sword itself, which is voiced by Logan Cunningham, the narrator of Bastion. The narration though isn't really narration as this time he is accompanying you on your adventure instead of talking about things in a past tense as it was with Bastion.  The game doesn't fail to please the eye with its distinct art style, which fits the tone of the story that show great resemblance to Blade Runner, with a touch a Tron, you will traverse through the roof tops, and city streets, and even the inside of a beast. Each location has some sort of hidden secret or a puzzle for you to solve in order to get through to the next area, they are pretty simple though, so don't expect anything too tough on the brain. There is a sanctuary of sorts that you discover that has training rooms for you to get better at the speed, planning, and learning how to survive more efficiently.    Which brings us to the true meat and potatoes of the game, is its combat system which mixes both real time combat, and turn based combat, with the latter being the most efficient way to get things done. Even some of the story is connected to the combat as you collect abilities, called functions, as each function has a character bio of a previous owner of the transistor or just noteworthy citizens of Cloudbank. You can unlock more of that character's background by equipping a function into an active slot , abilities that can be used in battle, upgrade slot, or a passive slot which encourages a lot of experimentation with abilities. It takes a little bit to get adjusted to, and while learning its not hard to win fights, its hard to win them with style. But once you get the hang of things you can always get the biggest bang for your buck. The combat system encourages experimentation, as when you lose all your health during a fight, you dont exactly die, but instead you lose a function and it gets taken out of your rotation for a while, while this may seem like a debilitating feature, this keeps players from the dull nature that min maxing brings and puts them right back into experimenting with other abilities.  While you can use abilities outside of the planning phase, the fact of the matter is that in most cases there are usually more mobs than you can handle, which in turn makes plan mode the only choice in dealing with most fights. Great for those who like to be strategic in their battles, not so great for those that just want to run in there and hack and slash. The game does have a new game plus feature for those that want to continue to go for achievements, and maybe to take a hidden path or two that you may have missed your first time around. There is no difficulty setting, although the higher level you go more mobs are thrown your way with upgraded abilities. To give your self more of a challenge, you have the option to apply limiters to your self, which is essentially a handicap feature. You can make the Process do more damage, make more spawn in a fight, or you can limit the amount of abilities that you have access to, to do get the results you want. It can get pretty rough, with quite a few limiters on, but each limiter adds a percentage bonus to experience that you get...and give you bit of bragging rights.   The story also isn't told in a conventional sense, as from the very start of the game you are thrown into the middle of a situation and left to figure things out on your own. You could probably complete the game a couple of times and still not understand everything around you. The only narration is through the sword itself, which is voiced by Logan Cunningham, the narrator of Bastion. The narration though isn't really narration as this time he is accompanying you on your adventure instead of talking about things in a past tense as it was with Bastion.  Supergiant games could have rested on the laurels of their success with Bastion, but decided to take a good risk and mix up the formula a bit with Transistor, which works good in some areas, and fall short in other. But all in all its a well made game with a bit of re-playability. I give Transistor a 4/5.

I was not hugely impressed with Transistor; those expecting something remotely as good as Bastion will be dissapointed. While the game is not bad by any stretch of the imagination, it wasn't quite the gem Bastion was.  The soundtrack was really good, but for some reason the developers thought it would be a good idea to hide a lot of it and make it unlockable via challenges. That makes no sense to me. The music that Darren Korb makes is amazing, I do not know why they would not take advantage of it at every turn to create the memorable experiences so many of us had with Bastion. The music being unlockable would not be that annoying to me had the game been more fun.  The game was not very fun for me, the controls felt clunky and while they encouraged experimenting with their system of augmenting abilities with other abilities to make different variations, it had the opposite effect of what they intended. The way the mechanics work, it encourages the player to combine greasy abilities together and just spam them. Their entire 'pause and plan the fight' system ended up making boss fights a matter of setting up three of the four abilities to cost more memory than your main one so that when you lost all your health you would just lose the abilities you did not care about. There was no strategy or skill involved, just simple math.  What the game did an amazing job at was the art. The game looks beautiful and stylish, blending great voice acting, beautiful environments and interesting enemy/character designs. The story is also a strong point. It does not show everything to people, and rewards those who take an interest and try to find as much information as possible. All of this coupled with a [SEMI-SPOILER] tragic yet beautiful ending left me liking the entire experience.  TLDR: Great story, beautiful art, good music, mediocre gameplay, not nearly as good as Bastion.
