... Buy this game...  Lets start with the ratings  OVERALL: 9/10  Gameplay: 10 Sound: 10 Replayability: 7 Story: 8  And now the reasoning. GAMEPLAY: 10 I came from Bastion, not realizing this was made by the same people until I started it up. In this case, that was a good thing, because I'd come to enjoy the old world charm of bastion and likely would have been turned off of the digital-world theme. However, I was rewarded almost instantly with my experience with Bastion and appreciated the enigmatic narrative taking a back seat to a consistant battle engine that was fun to play and catered to whatever my mood happened to be at the time, 'Turn' based combat, or real time. Enemy variety was interesting and posed different challenges based on my abilities and the 'terrain' in each fight. This aspect seems lost to many developers who simply script enemies with more health and hit harder without adding any depth to the combat. The ability customizability absolutely roped me in. I adore being able to customize loadouts in attempts to maximize potential of one aspect or another.  One of my favorite builds wasn't even the most powerful. Charming enemies for long periods of time and letting them kill each other while my pet ran around helping them, and collecting cells spawned more temporary friendly minions. I was having, dare I say it, FUN!  It allows people to take on whatever role is comfortable and play through the game at their own speed and play style.  I gotta give them props for the ability variety and how effective they are based on what enemy types are present.   SOUND: 10 No conflicting information. Every sound quickly becomes associated with the result happening on the screen. And the soundtrack fits the narrative. And like that cheesy review I read about pausing to listen to Red sing... Darn it if I didn't do the same thing...  My tab key got stuck several times. >_>  REPLAYABILITY: 7 I am grading this more harshly due to the fact that there ARE side challenges that you can complete to elongate the original play through, but they aren't available to you again after that. While being able to replay through the story does allow you to catch things you may have missed on the first pass, it doesn't offer too much else. However, I still catch myself playing through the story from time to time, just to remember the smart design of it all.  STORY: 8  I felt there was a few more questions to be answered, or things that could have been available to those who wanted more information. I read as much text as I could find in order to learn more about this world and the city, and was admittedly a bit disappointed in not knowing the origins of the town and other such things. BUT ONLY A BIT! The rest of the narrative was very well done, and allowed the player to fill in the gaps without insulting their intelligence. I still remember the surprise from the begining of the game resulting in immediate intrigue...   TLDR; It's a bit pricey for how long it lasts, but the entire experience is QUALITY for the time spent, in my opinion. If you catch it on sale, even at 25%... pick it up if it seems interesting to you. I seriously doubt you'll be disappointed.

Transistor is definitely one of the most unique video games I've ever played, and easily stands as my game of 2014. It's a linear, narrative-driven action RPG with a lush, beautiful and unique art style. It's the aesthetic of this game that hits you first; it looks incredible and obvious love and immense skill have gone into the hand-drawn environments, giving the game a very 'textured' feel. Although the game is linear, the detailing in the art makes you feel like you could wander off the rails at any moment you choose.  The second thing that hits you with Transistor is the music. Employing moody, atmospheric trip-hop style soundscapes, Transistor's soundtrack is achingly beautiful and complements the melancholy story and cyberpunk visuals perfectly. The soundtrack is further enhanced by several incredible vocal performances by Ashley Barrett, who brings a languid, jazz-inflected feel to the songs. Not only does Ashley Barrett's voice add a poignant humanity to the music, it also enhances the story through its lyrics.  Speaking of story, this game employs a sparse narrative, creating a sense of roleplay by having you piece together events at the same pace Red does. This game does not hold your hand through the narrative and you'll have to read every scrap of lore, listen to every bit of dialogue and take in every cryptic clue in the song lyrics to help you make sense of Transistor's enigmatic narrative. This put some people off, but I personally loved it. This narrative pieceing makes it feel like the story unfolds organically, with any furthering of the narrative being a result of *your* actions, as opposed to have bits of story crammed down your throat when the game deems it necessary. It's a very Dark Souls-esque way of doing things and I loved it.  As to the narrative itself, I won't spoil it, but Transistor tells the story of Red, an enchanting singer in the city of Cloudbank whose voice has been taken from her, and a mysterious man whose soul (taking the form of computer data) has been trapped in the assassin's blade meant for you. Together, you undertake a journey to get revenge and find out what's happening to your city as it is overrun by aggressive robots known as 'the process.'   Now, on to gameplay. Transistor employs a mixture of real time combat and a pseudo-turn based system, whereby Red freezes time, chooses attacks to perform and then executes these actions at lightning speed. It's an interestng gimmick that allows you to deal with the often overwhelming number of enemies you'll face on your own. Where Transistor's gameplay really shines is in its 'Function' system. Functions are essentially abilities that can be slotted as either passive or activated, granting passive buffs or usable abilities. However, each function can also be slotted as an upgrade to another function, augmenting it with different characteristics and buffs. This means that you have essentially endless variety in your ability loadouts, with each ability changing itself drastically depending on which other functions you pair it with. It's an elegant and extremely fun system, if a little poorly explained in-game, and it makes Transistor a very unique experience among action RPGs.  I could honestly wax lyrical about Transistor all day, but what it really comes down to is this; do you want an action RPG with a unique and inventive combat system that encourages creativity, visuals and sound design to die for, and a sparse, melancholy story that unfolds in a slow, organic manner? If not, don't buy this game.   If that sounds like your kettle of fish, then welcome to Cloudbank.

On top of that, the game rewards you for trying out new function combinations by revealing more about the town and its residents as you do so, encouraging the player to try new and creative forms of gameplay. This is reinforced even more by a very fare learning curve that first allows you to get use to the system, then insists you think about trying to make strong function combinations. Though the curve is on the easier side, like Bastion, the game offers 'limiters' that can be turned on and off at checkpoints to increase the difficulty in numerious ways.  Supergiant put alot of effort into trying to craft a game that wasn't Bastion 2, while sticking to their specific art style and narrative strengths. Transistor is the second game by independent studio Supergiant Games, following in the footsteps of their debut masterpiece, Bastion. Although the two games work off similar perspectives and narrative styles, featuring a silent (or in this case, mute) protagonist and a single supporting character that provides narration, Transistor feels and plays fundamentally different from its predecessor.  Where Bastion was a whimsically-styled fantasy featuring traditional real-time combat and a wealth of customization, Transistor is initially much more bare-boned and linear, and decidedly more mournful in its jazz-age cyberpunk aesthetic. Red, the player character, is clearly not a soldier or adventurer like the Kid, so combat takes on a much more measured pace as you plan moves from your Turn() bar, execute them in accelerated time, then run from enemies while Turn() recharges. The Transistor is the source of your power, and is in many ways as much a character as Red herself. New Functions are unlocked as you progress through the world, allowing you a greater variety of options in to deal with new foes. Also, as in Bastion, Limiters can be enabled to increase the qualitative difficulty of the game.  The story is narrated by an unnamed male character, whose voice emanates from the Transistor. Through his eyes, you are provided insights into Red's past, as well as the history and culture of Cloudbank and the myserious power group called the Camerata. Text files attached to the Traces of deceased characters will unlock with use of their associated Functions, allowing an even deeper look into the mysteries of Cloudbank and its fall.  Overall, I found Transistor to be a masterfully crafted narrative, with art and musical assets to match. The game's unorthodox approach to narrative style and combat may be off-putting to some, and is certainly a departure from previous games of the genre. Additionally, the ability to rotate the camera to avoid foreground obstructions is never properly explained, despited being extremely helpful even in early stages of the game. Slight technical quibbles aside, I do not hesistate to give Transistor my highest recommendation.  With Transistor, Supergiant has continued their tradition of aesthetically unique world-building and narrative excellence.

To be honest I wan't sure if to write this review. Why? Well, at almost 9500 positive reviews that most likely covered what I might have to say it seems a bit pointless. Nonetheless - after the 2nd playthrough - I decided to write one as a 'thank-you' note to Supergiant Games.  If you have already played Bastion you probably know what to expect here. The game is in the same vain albeit with some different mechanics. I'll keep it short and by points.  Pros: - Story: the story isn't mush new, but so was Bastion. What differentiates it from others is the narration and progress. - Visuals: the style consists of a beautifully drawn sci-fi world and blends nicely with the story. - Music: what's more to say? It's from the music director who worked on Bastion [+more songs this time]. - Combat: I found the attack customization engaging in developing different play-styles. Plus, the option to play either a hack-n-slash or take your time and plan the attacks can be refreshing when you get tired of one or the other.  Cons: - Short: the game can be finished in less than 10 hours [my stats are inflated for idealing for cards and achievement hunting]. I don't regret for buying the game, but I did buy it on sale. -Replayability: it really becomes an issue only because the game is rather short.  Overall: Get it if you liked Bastion and if the shortness bothers you, get it on sale.

Transistor is one of my most favorite games ever.  I picked it up after I accidentally stumbled upon Bastion and fell in love with it, only to experience the same, if not better, feeling again. The art is unique, the soundtrack incredibly good, and the overall atmosphere is enthralling and beautiful.  The fighting system is a kind of a mix of real-time and turn-based combat. You are given a certain number of points represented as bar and you can spend those points on performing abilities uncluding movement, think mana or energy. This whole 'picking a move' phase happens when the game is paused, but the excution itself is real time. You can use your moves any time on their own too, but this 'tactical' way is more effective.  You level up through gaining experience points, but since the individual game levels are pretty much straigthforward corridors, there's no grinding involved and the experience points come sort of naturally, without any big effort. What matters though is what you spend them on. You can either buy a new skill, unlock an upgrade slot for a move you already have an older one, or increase your memory, which in turn increases the number of moves you can have at any single time. You can't always do all of the above, but that's pretty much how it works.  On death, you lose some of your moves untill you 'recharge' at specific bind points or lose all of your moves and die. That can be kind of irritating since if the move randomly deactivated happens to be your main source of damage, you're pretty much screwed. Although it brings in a certain level of challengem it can be a lot painful.  The story is captivating, reflecting the overall mood of the game. Similarly to Bastion, there's only one narrator, which only adds to the unique feelings of the empty city.  Great game, totally recommend it.

If you focus on these pieces of the game individually it's hard to deny them.  On the other hand, there is a painful repetition with each combat sequence. There is not enough time in between combat to really explore. When there is time to explore there is not much to find. Character development feels limited and unrewarding. These short comings can make the game just boring at times and is why I can not recommend this game.

It's a pretty game and is certainly intriguing. It has interesting gameplay mechanics - mainly the turn based grid system, the interesting number of skills and it's combinations, modifiers etc. - it has a nice feeling of progression.  That said, it never becomes a good game. Why? I'll tell you: while it has all of that mentioned above, it has no interesting challenges (except, perhaps, for the last Boss), enemies or encounters. It takes place in corridor levels and has no interludes or content besides combat and some challenges (that is, more combat!).  On top of that, the game sabotages itself by locking certain features in order to punish the players for failure. In combat you can only use your skills (except for Jaunt, as a main or as accessory) when your turn bar is filled up. Since you'll often use your turns to avoid punishment, it means that you are disallowed to do anything besides moving while the bar fills up again. And when you get beaten, instead of restarting, you lose one of your four skills, making combat poorer while it remains and for at least two more save points. You probably will just reset it instead of trying new stuff.  The story is pretentious. It can be pieced together and it is really quite simple at the end, but it fails from the get go to instigate the player in it's quest for retribution. You won't look forward to unveil anything, since you'll only get breadcrumbs and too little to work with.  Thus meh/10.

For some reason the game is split into a series of sevral arenas so the quality measures all fall down to (a) arena design and (b) combat.  The arenas only differ in shape and composition of enemies. There's not much space to shine but also not much space to ♥♥♥♥ up. Yet, some arenas are so bad you have big trouble moving in them as desired. And since moving while doing ♥♥♥♥ all is for some reason an integral part of the fighting system there are some bottleneck arenas ready to boost your ragequit potential. I filled mine. Fighting in this game is not hard, it's imprecise, that's the problem. A big one for partialy real time game.  The combat system could be great. It incorporates very Magicka-esque system of combining attacks from a set of fragments. Whether or not the unlockable limitations on you should be considered a design failure is up to you. I felt like I was presented with great set of tools to be creative with, while the dev only allowed me to carry either a mininuke and nothing else or a screwdriver, knife and a hammer. It's unnecessary. Even then the system is fun to toy with so itîs saddening but ok. However the combat has one big problem and that is phasing. You can either go with real-time cooldown base Diablo which doesn't work well (on purpose) or you enter a turn planning phase in which you give a sequence of actions to your hero and upon release she executes them. Combos and positioning all matter which is very good. However after the turn execution comes a ENJOY NOTHING phase where all your actions are limited to walking around at a constant speed trying to evade enemies and their shots and WAITING FOR YOUR TURN BAR TO FILL UP. Jesus ♥♥♥♥ that's stupid.  But it sure looks and sounds pretty.

Leading the player through the futuristic city of Cloudbank, Transistor doesn't hold your hand and present you with billboard-obvious explanations. Collect information if you like, interpret it at your own discretion. What exactly is the invasion/contagion of the Process? What exactly were the Camerata's original intentions? Parse it out. Or don't.  The gameplay encourages you to experiment with combat mechanics, but it is uncluttered enough not to give a casual player trouble. Personally, if variety didn't offer additional information, I likely would've stuck to the first couple of combinations unlocked -- but mix and match turned out to be fun.  The art style is bright, vibrant colors, never garish. I enjoyed the city thoroughly, just as I did the soundtrack -- oh the vocals, it's gonna be in my playlist for next several months at least.   Perhaps the most unexpected thing turned out to be, well, the story. It's sad. I had to get up and walk away from my laptop a couple of times to simply calm down. It's a story (surprisingly) about love. Not a sweeping tragic romance, it's barely spoken of really. But love is the bookends of Transistor and everything in-between the beginning and the finale is steeped in it. A bittersweet feeling. It's beautiful. Expect to cry.

Bastion was a lovely surprise in the summer of 2011, easily weedling it's way to the very top of my list of favorite games. Supergiant Games was instantly put on my radar after their first game, so I was delighted to find out that they were making another game. However, I fell into this idea that it would just be impossible for them to make a game as memorable and creative as Bastion. I was very wrong. Transistor is simply a masterpiece.   Pros- - Beautiful art direction and fluid animation - Memorable characters and excellent voice work by Logan Cunningham - Interesting combat with varied skills and combinations - Satisfying progression - Twists on gameplay via 'Limiters' - Quirky interactions between the main cast - New Game Plus - Great Developers - Divine OST  Cons- - Camera can (very rarely) be cumbersome due to architecture - Story can be somewhat difficult to follow early on (didn't detract from my experience, though others may find it jarring) - I wish there was more of it; completed my initial playthrough in roughly 6 1/2 hours.   In short: If you played Bastion and loved it, play Transistor. If you're looking for a game with great design and all around excellent craftsmanship, play Transistor. If you're looking for something different, play Transistor. And so, with all things said and done- play Transistor.

While the game has no difficulty settings, it does have a set of 'Limiters' to amp up the difficulty by warping some of the core gameplay mechanics, making it increasingly difficult to survive and move through the story with each one activated.  Darren Korb once again provides a masterful score of music, along with Ashley Barrett representing the protagonist, Red, in the vocals. While the total score is a masterpiece, listening to it pre-emptively can and will spoil much of the symbolism and plot of the game, so I don't recommend it. However, the game itself is worth playing just for the music.  The art style is gorgeous, and is one of the game's defining features. Coupled with the narration which one of the main characters does throughout the entire storyline, voiced by Logan Cunningham - the same narrator from Bastion! - the game never feels empty or alone. With a silent protagonist, and one who won't shut up and describes everything that happens in Mr. Cunningham's beautiful and skilled voice, you learn to fall in love with the characters.  Overall, I one-hundred-percent recommend Transistor to any and all. It's a 10/10, and the only flaw is that it's short, and ends abruptly - despite this, the plot fits perfectly to end here, and it creates a more artistic, and complete piece with the ending.

From the creators of Bastion, Transistor is a sci-fi themed action RPG that invites you to wield an extraordinary weapon of unknown origin as you fight through a stunning futuristic city. Transistor seamlessly integrates thoughtful strategic planning into a fast-paced action experience, melding responsive gameplay and rich atmospheric storytelling. During the course of the adventure, you will piece together the Transistor's mysteries as you pursue its former owners.   Key Features  An all-new world from the team that created Bastion  Configure the powerful Transistor with thousands of possible Function combinations  Action-packed real-time combat fused with a robust strategic planning mode  Vibrant hand-painted artwork in full 1080p resolution  Original soundtrack changes dynamically as the action unfolds  Hours of reactive voiceover create a deep and atmospheric story  'Recursion' option introduces procedural battles after finishing the story  Fully customizable controls custom-tailored for PC

As far as the combat goes, you really should use the optional 'limiters' to increase the strategic depth of the fights. That's when the combat system really shines. Essentially the game starts on the easiest difficulty and gives you the option to make it harder at a faster rate when you gain levels. Though if the main story leaves you wanting a little more fulfillment, the side challenges are fantastic and make great use of the combat.  As for the story, it's much more along the lines of a sci-fi short story than Bastion was, though it still has their very distinct method of narrative progression. While it certainly shares a significant amount of the narrative structure from Bastion, it... This is kinda hard to explain, but it seems to me that Transistor is driven more by themes and ideas, whereas Bastion was driven more by relational emotion (emotion of relationships?). That's not to say Transistor doesn't have a strong theme of relationship, it very much does, but it's quieter. It stirs in the backdrop. Once the big event has done its course, its brought in to the forefront as if the character is saying, 'My only intention was ever this. All else was coincidental, to me.'  I've seen some reviews that said the ending was not very emtionally satisfying, but I think that's because (and this may be somewhat spoilerish, but should actually enhance your experience) the main character's goals are different from what the player might be tricked into thinking her goal is.  So yeah, I like it.

You're probably like me and went in with the mindset of 'There's no way it can be better than Bastion.'  Folks, they did it.  Let me get the negatives out of the way: It's as short as Bastion, especially if you skip the challenge mode stuff. Also I ran into a handful of areas with very significant framerate drops.  But here are the reasons you should get this game: -Incredible story from beginning to end. There are still questions left after the (amazing) ending, but they're not significant enough to detract from the overall narrative. -Interesting combat system. I wasn't sold on the combat after seeing the initial trailer, but after getting a few abilities I discovered just how well designed the combat is. It's fun, it's challenging, it can vary wildly from playstyle to playstyle, and it just works. -Really neat upgrade system. You only have 4 'active' abilities, however you very quickly obtain more than that. The abilities that are not being used can be put into the upgrade slots of the active abilities. As an example, One ability has the power to generate explosives. When putting that ability into your default 'swing' ability, your swing now does AoE damage. Also, much of the lore and backstory is hidden behind unlocks in these abilities. By using these abilities in battle, either as an 'active' ability or an upgrade, you unlock a tiny bit more lore. It's a fantastic way to both immerse the player further into the world and also encourage them to try out all of the abilities. -The music. Get the soundtrack. No question about it. If you played Bastion, you know exactly how amazing the soundtrack is.  This is the best game I have played this year. The guys over at Supergiant are truly masters of their craft. 10/10

Five hours in so far and I must say I'm loving it. Similar art style to bastion but with a digital and art nouveau coat of paint. The story is interesting and has some rather deep themes of self determination and a p[erson's place in a near utopian world. It's nice to see the idea of people trying to make a utopia better, it is an over looked plot idea. On top of that the game is a wonder to play. The combat is deep and layered, with a lot of the choices firmly under player control. The game encourages actively varying one's play style as it is the only way to learn more about the world and the people in it. The turn mechanics is interesting and does require thought and preparation, as things don't always work out the way you expect them to, esspecially later when enemies begin to passively inteact with you when the time stop is enabled. So far my only qualms are with the default mouse and keyboard controls, they just seem a bit awkward, if you're determined to play on mouse and keyboard I would advise binding the abilities to buttons on the mouse, or just using a controller, the controls are very tight and most of the time precision is only required when using Turn, and those mistakes can be undone easily. $20 may seem a bit steep but this game is worth it. If you can't aford it then I would highly adivse putting it on your wishlist and grabbing it as soon as it goes on sale, or watch the Humble Bundle page like a hawk. Suffice to say, Super Giant Games has done it again and created another game that I will hold up with a 'Games are Art' sign.

Platform: PC Version: 1.01 Unlike many indie games, Transistor has some very big shoes to fill, but developers Super Giant Games have only themselves to blame for this.  In case you think the developer’s name is familiar, it should be. They’re responsible for the fantastic Bastion. Released in 2011 for the Xbox 360 and Steam, Bastion was a ‘sleeper hit’. A fantastic top-down action RPG, with an excellent story, thoroughly enjoyable characters, great gameplay and beautiful art style. Bastion had it all going on.  Needless to say, I entered into Transistor with high hopes. But fortunately, Transistor not only met my expectations, it exceeded them.  Set in the futuristic sci-fi city of Cloudbank, Transistor sees you take control of the character Red, one of the most renowned singers within the Cloudbank. You start the game lost and under heavy pursuit from the ‘Process’. Fortunately, you quickly discover the mystical great sword called the ‘Transistor’ buried in the chest of some poor unfortunate soul.  From the moment you wield the Transistor, the constant narration begins. Logan Cunningham reprises his role of narrator here, a role he played exceptionally well in Bastion. And much the same as Bastion, the majority of the game’s narrative is told through this narration. However, you’ll also find terminals throughout the world that house short news stories, polls and character profiles. Interestingly you’re able to interact with these news stories by casting votes in certain polls and posting replies to stories.  The various ways in which the story is told make it very easy to pick up whilst exploring the world, and without getting bogged down by heavy dialogue scenes or pages of in game text. It’s up to you how much you get out of Transistor, but exploring the world of Cloudbank City is something you’re certainly going to want to do. Like Bastion before it, the art style in Transistor is beautiful and that alone compelled me to explore every corner of the city to see as much of it as possible.  The combination of excellent storytelling, beautiful art style and a simply fantastic soundtrack all work well to suck you into the world of Cloudbank City and simply won’t let go. All things considered, Cloudbank is an extremely enjoyable place to be, or rather it would be were it not for the ‘Process’ hounding your every move.  The Process are robotic minions under the control of the Camerata, the group who tried – and failed – to assassinate Red using the Transistor. So her quest to defeat the Camerata sees Red clearing each section of Cloundbank City of the Process.  The combat is a mixture between a real-time and turn-based system. You can run about freely attacking enemies, but after a time runs down, you can pause the action and plan your attacks and movements, in a similar style to the V.A.T.S system featured in the latest Fallout Games. Then, once you’ve selected your movements, once the game is un-paused, Red will quickly perform the actions. The option to pause the combat and plan your attacks certainly adds an enjoyable depth of tactical decision-making to the game and due to the variety in different combat moves that are presented in the form of ‘memory modules’ you attach to the Transistor, there is a lot of depth to be found in Transistor’s combat. The memory modules themselves can be found, or rather, extracted from the few corpses littered throughout Cloudbank. These modules do appear rather baffling at first, I certainly felt overwhelmed with options, but as you become more accustomed to the combat, so it becomes easier to explore and combine the different modules to shake up the attack options available to Red. Before long, you’ll soon figure out which ones work best for you.  Here-in lies the only fault I’ve found with Transistor, Despite the variety of move-sets on offer, toward the midpoint of the game – especially in the later sections – the combat started to become rather repetitive. As soon as I found which combination of memory modules would allow me to dispatch my enemies the most efficiently, there was little inspiration for me to delve any deeper into lesser-used modules.  That’s not to say that Transistor gets easy, just that the combat soon descended into me moving through motions until either the fight was over or I died.  Death, however, is another aspect that Transistor approaches differently. Once Red has sustained enough damage, a module becomes damaged and becomes unavailable during that fight. As a result, you’re going to have to wait until you’ve made it to the next area before repairs can be made. It’s an interesting twist on the combat, yet I found it only worked to slow the combat down, which can also be said about the ‘Turn’ system. Red can only use her attacks if the charge meter is filled and using the Turn system will, more often than not, deplete the charge bar leaving you run around helpless until it recharges.  Also at odds with the pace of the game is the challenge system. Every so often, at different points in Transistor, you’re given the chance to exit the actual game world to a relaxing seaside resort hub-world. This hub-world is populated with a couple of doors that present different challenges behind each, such as defeating x amount of enemies in an alotted time. I found the different challenges to be quite frustrating at times and certainly didn’t find that they fitted in well with the rather ‘laid-back’ nature of the main game. However, the reward of unlocking additional music from the soundtrack was certainly worth it as Darren Kob, composer of the music in Bastion, has simply out done himself yet again with Transistor.  Transistor is a very different beast to its older sibling Bastion despite the obvious similarities. It’s slower paced and certainly more atmospheric and it represents a game studio that have matured over the course of development of both games. I’m certainly finding myself exploring every corner of the world in order to learn as much about Red and the mysterious Transistor that I can. And the great thing, the more I learn, the further I want to explore. How many games can you say that about?  The Good Stuff  Enthralling narrative and characters. Beautiful art style. The excellent soundtrack is worth the price tag alone. The Bad Stuff  Combat becomes repetitive all too quickly. Challenges can be quite frustrating … I don’t want it to end…  Final Analysis  Transistor is certainly the most enjoyable game I’ve played this year. It offers up a world full of mystery and emotion. The narrative will suck you and set you searching through the beautifully drawn world of Cloudbank City on a quest to learn as much as possible. The few characters in the game are steeped with personality, helped only by the constant narration from the, once again, excellent Logan Cunningham.  Quite simply, you’ll find yourself falling in love with Transistor every second you spend in its world.  Techical Competency – 8/10  Graphic Quality – 9/10  Sound Quality – 10/10  Network Stability – NA  Overall 9/10

There are few games that make us choke up; there are even fewer games that we take the time to play twice before we review. Transistor achieves both – it’s just that gripping. I have just completed the main story and felt compelled to write a quick review for it. (no spoilers)   First up, the art direction and graphical design in this game is stunning. The atmosphere is beautiful and immersive. A stellar soundtrack magnifies the atmosphere to produce an overall, somewhat noire, cyberpunk theme for the game. The voice acting is top notch, serving only to enhance the in game experience and the storyline is enjoyable, intriguing, and well thought out.  The combat is innovative with an RPG-turn based strategy hybrid style which was a learning curve to begin with, but hugely rewarding to grasp. I found the game to be challenging in terms of difficulty, which I see as a good thing (though different people will have varying levels of skill). There are side training challenges, which you can sink hours into, as they get progressively harder. It also has a recursive mode after the game for enhanced replayability and challenge, though I am yet to explore this in any real depth.  So overall, I absolutely recommend this game. For a game coming from an indie developer (like seriously the credits are real short. they're over in a minute) this is simply sublime and competes with the big titles.

This masterpiece combines the best of Tron and Final Fantasy: through its innovative strategic utilities, it's digital feel, and it's heartwarming storyline.   This game approaches combat it two ways, you can hunt down your enemies in real time, or use the power of the Transistor, Turn(), to stop time. Once time is stopped you can plan your attack, and execute it in extreme speed. The game is set in a digital world, which is very reminiscing of Tron. Without spoiling too much, the population determines how the surrounding environment looks, and votes on how their world should change. In this democratic society, Camerata form a villainous plot to change the world for the 'better'. During the execution of this plan, Red, a musician in this world, and the Transistor are united and join forces to battle the villainy of the Camerata and the mysterious Process that now plagues their digital paradise.  Although the campaign is short, about 8 hours with detours, the difficult fast paced scenarios, and gorgeous graphics more than make up for the game's brevity. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys strategic, and immersive gameplay, as well as phenomenal storytelling.

TL;DR? skip to last paragraph    PROS  Transistor was amazing. For me one the biggest selling points was the soundtrack, so if you have the cash I would definetly suggest buying it with the soundtrack. The soundtrack was beautiful, and most of all, cohesive. It set the mood for epic boss fights and help relax at the more calm and chill parts of the game.  The story was also beautiful focusing mostly around the relationship between the main characters, and the item that joins them. I won't spoil anything but know that everything that happens fits into the story somehow, leading to a great ending. The connection between the characters felt real and was enough to make me feel actual emotions *gasp*. The visuals are also amazing ...  in thier own way.  In kinda the way you begin to appreciate the graphics behind borderlands or dishonest, transistor has graphics that grow on you. Its has a very unique art style the looks like a fusion a western cartoons and japanese anime. There was never a time when I was dissapointed with the graphics so rest assured that they are good.  Lastly, the combat was more satisfying than you can imagine. It has a great combination of reactive responses, and strategy. The game forces you to plan out your stategy, but leaves room to go wild on your enemies. Knowing how and when to use abilities is key. The combat is also quite punishing as your lifes are attached to your skills, so if you plan poorly you might just lose your best skills for a while.    CONS  And now the honest truths. The story is short, and I mean  really short . Only 6-7 hours of gameplay. To compensate there is an extended game mode where you can play again with your old abilites but tbh the replay value is minimal  (buying the soundtrack helps make it last longer!) .  Also for all the strengths of the combat the process of setting up your skills seemed clunky and ill desingned. Also the tutorial was very minimal, which didn't help with the getting used to transitor's unique system.  Also in terms of story if you like clarity and for everything to be explianed out perfectly (like I do) you will be dissapointed. They do expect you to fill in the gaps with hints but there are just certain elements that I feel could've been explained better.   In Closing, Transistor was a great game with new and inivative combat, stunning soundtrack, unique visuals, and a story deep enough to get an elephant to drown in a pool of his own tears. Unfortunately it was extremely short, had clunky controls at times, and the story left you with more unanwsered questions than an SAT. 8.5/10 definite good buy.

So after some time with the game, getting to know its in's and out's, I'm changing up my review to reflect on some things I find lacking with the game's design.  TLDR version: With a heavy heart I give this game a 7.5 out of 10. While the atmosphere, soundtrack, voice work and overall idea of the game are top notch, there are some conflicting designs within the game that are just too glaring to let slide. The good news, the game could make a small patch TOMORROW if they cared to, that would fix these issues and bump the game up to a 10/10 in a heartbeat.  First issue. I dont lke the idea that when you die, you lose skills. What this translates to in game is if I die, I pause the game and hit 'retry' immediately. It would be nice if there was a toggle in the options menu to make this the norm. This is more a nitpick which doesn't bring the game's score down, but still a minor inconvenience.  Second: I'm not a fan of one of the 'limiters' being a removal of 'memory' for putting more skills in. The game should get harder as you as a player find more tools and cominations to meet that challenge. Indeed the rise in difficulty should be an impetous for the player to put more and more things together to overcome thsoe challenges. When a challenge is, 'Hey, you now get less tools to work with, k?' then what happens is very degenerative gameplay where the metagame now shifts to: 'Find the most memory efficient set of skills to break the game mechanics for this fight.' The answer to said question 9.9 times out of 10 is, 'Perma stun, always perma stun'. Remove the limiter and replace it with something more interesting. Fix this and the game is an 8 out of 10.  Third: If the second weren't bad enough on its own, a new limiter called 'Permanence' pops up. Firstly, a warning that it stays in effect EVEN WHEN TOGGLED OFF would be awesome, just awesome. But now consider the following 3 things: The fights in this game change drastically to the point that what 'breaks the game' for one fight is utterly useless for another. Due to my second issue, you have terrible memory and thus only have access to one cookie cutter build at a time. In new game plus, overloaded skills stay overloaded for ? time, and uninstalling a skill to change builds uninstalls a skill. What? Giving the limiter a warning would bump you up to an 8.5.  Also consider that you now get 'copies of skills' in NG+ which can fundamentally alter your builds. To make use of them, you have to uninstall skills to make room evven without a memory shortage. The entire way this game is designed is just not consistent with the idea of permanent skills, at least not unless you're max level and have enough memory to make a well balanced build. Maybe make it a thing for a challenge mode or something? This change wouldn't effect rating, since I could always attempt to turn off my 'must play game on hardest mode OCD' and just turn it on at the end of the game, but it would be nice nonetheless.  Fourth: Your entire NG+ system is broken. So here' my current situation in game currently. I deleted all my skills just to see how many the game would let me delete. Turns out I can't delete less than 3. The 3 I hafve are useless and thus can't progress past the fight I'm on. The 'Reset progress' option doesn't start me at the beginning of NG+ with all my skills, it starts me back at the beginning of the entire original playthrough. How about no? Your design philosophy was to be respectful of player's time, and most of the game thus far has been. This, however, is a huge oversight. As far as making the game remember what skills you started out with after the last boss fight, how about we make that irrelevant. Just when enterring NG+ for the first time and every subsequent time via restarts, make the 'Prepare yourself!' message pop up so you can pick your skills and get moving. There, problem solved. Fix this, and even if you FIXED NOTHING ELSE, I'd bump this game up to a 9.5 out of 10.  Other than these large gripes, my main general gripe is that most attacks are too slow outside of Turn(). More or less half of my skills get relegated to 'upgrade or passive' status because they're more of a liability to use in harder battles than anything else. Some general TLC for attack animations for some skills would go a long way.

I'm not an expert in genre definition, but I think this is what modern-day cyberpunk is like - less rainy undertown swarming with cyber-implanted punks and more cloud storage wrapped in a sleek casing and filled with the souls of hipsters.  It's all about the mood - the humming, the colours, the spotlights, the show posters, the news terminals. The way Red writes comments and sometimes uses them to talk to her lover, who's right next to her, because that's the only way she CAN do it - that's a trifle (just one of many) that plays really well into the whole picture. It's a kind of melodic despair, a sweetly aching melancholy.  Get the soundtrack. It's as much part of the story as anything else, Ashley Barrett's voice a flashback to just before the game begins, when Red still had hers.  Combat... well, it's there. You can whack 'em in real-time, Diablo-style, or you can plan your moves for maximum tactical efficiency - the game has a built-in 'challenge mode' for all styles. The system where you use skills as upgrades for other skills, or as separate passive skills, is interesting. But again, it's all about the mood and the story here - because every skill is a person, and you learn their story by using the skill in various ways.  The game is horribly short, but I get the feeling that it's exactly long enough. Sometimes a short story should be a short story. It shouldn't be sold for the price of a whole book, though.

It's difficult for me to write a review of this game. See, I bought it out of a passionate love for Supergiant Games that came forth from playing their first game, Bastion. Now, as this was my motivation, I think it's fair to speak it in terms of its merits relative to the game that caused me to purchase it. Overall, I say that I recommend the game, but that it isn't worth the money for the amount of gameplay you get.   Visuals:  As in Bastion, the artwork was stunning. In fact, this is the main element in which Transistor far surpasses Supergiant  Games's first title. Nowadays, it's difficult to find a truly beautiful game that also plays relatively well. In Transistor, the city of Cloudbank is beautiful, filled with bright lights and dark shadows, each skyline and city street more breathtaking than the last. This was the most impressive aspect of the game, in my mind.   Audio: Again like Bastion, the audio was excellent. However, for a game whose main character is a singer (even though she has lost her voice), I saw very little focus on the musical aspect of the game. Unlike in Bastion, where I found myself seeking out and listening to the music after playing the game, I was not captivated. I was disappointed by this, but still found the music to be very enjoyable. I wish that you had the option to listen to the music you unlocked outside of the enclosed zone (that would've been very nice).   Gameplay: This is the part that most disappointed me. I saw a lot of good ideas in terms of combat in Transistor. The ability to place any skill in a primary, secondary, or passive slot allowed for a lot of different and interesting builds. The idea of the Turn() was pretty cool, as well. However,    it made the boss battle a Dragonball-Z like turn-based battle, and    I always found myself flailing around after using it, avoiding conflict until it recharged, then immediately using it again. This was not fun for me. It had a couple of good ideas, but some of them were poorly executed, leading to an unsatisfactory combat experience.   Story: I'm kinda on the fence about this. The characters seem interesting, but again, in relative terms, it wasn't as good as Bastion. There was not enough detail given. In bastion, the story revolved around a core of a small number of characters, who were characterized by their actions and reactions to objects and events. You were told enough to keep you on your seat, keep you guessing, and keep you invested. The characters seemed to matter. With Transistor, I only cared about the two main characters, and not as much as I did with Bastion. Again, disappointment is the main feeling. They could've done better.  Value:  I don't think the game is worth the cost. I spent $15 on about 4 actual hours of gameplay (I had 6 on record because I left it open to go eat), which is not okay. Most $60 games offer at least 1 hour of gamplay for each dollar spent. I felt cheated, to be frank. I had fun, but it wasn't worth it. I'd recommend playing it, but perhaps not purchasing it.

If you liked Bastion you'll like this game. If you didn't like Bastion you probably wont enjoy the game very much.  If you've never played Bastion you can think of this game as an Isometric (Read: Top-down view at an angle) action-adventure game where you acquire abilities to use while alternating between real-time and turn-based combat. These abilities can be combined with one another to create new hybrids of abilities which extends the life of the game's combat system dramatically. The story is told as you explore with a handful of minimalist cutscenes thrown in which showcase the 2d art style. Understanding the story requires the player to pay careful attention to dialogue and explore the environments for context.  The game is about 6 hours long and may be repeated in New Game+ (Recursion Mode) to continue acquiring abilities and attempt more difficult combat challenges. A repeated playthrough is also recommended to see the story through again with the context given to you by the initial playthrough. This is the kind of game they have long articles written dedicated to piecing together what was really going on in the game's story, without being the kind of game that you'll find yourself completely confused by if you choose not to engage in the larger conversation happening around the game's opening and ending.  $20 is a steal. If you're into Indie titles, Bastion, or want to explore what indie titles have to offer to the video games market this isn't a bad place to start.

I absolutely loved Bastion, so I was losing my mind while waiting for Super Giant's next game. They did not disappoint. I expected to have a beautiful art style and a great soundtrack along with fun gameplay. The art is gorgeous and the character model for the player also looks good. That was my one complaint about Bastion, because The Kid looked strange during gameplay, despite looking cool in concept art and cut scenes. But Transistor looks beautiful all across the board. The soundtrack is also incredible and perfectly fits the game.  The gameplay is something that I have never played before. You have the option of fighting as an action game, which works well against small enemies. However, against tougher enemies, you will be killed easily fighting this way. Instead, you use a system called functions where you stop time and plan out what moves you will use. This system offers you a limited number of moves and makes this more of a strategy game compared to Bastion. While this slows down gameplay, it is still fun and tense.  All in all, I highly recommend this game to everyone. Anyone who enjoyed Bastion should absolutely give it a try.

This game is beautiful, the music is great, the voice acting is great and the combat is superb. The move system of this game is quite deep; as you progress you earn more moves (up to 20 or so), and you have up to 4 slots for combat and up to 4 slots for passives. The depth for the moves comes from the fact that each skill/move you learn can be assigned to either one of you your 4 slots, your passive, or as a modifier to another move (up to 2 for each slot) you have assigned to you main slots; I can not stress how much depth this gives and I barely scratched the surface for all the cool combos you can set up in my one play through. For the vast majority of people, the chief reason why they would be eyeing up Transistor is summed up in seven letters: its predecessor, Bastion. For those not in the know, Bastion was a single-player action-slanted RPG with a unique art style and interspersed with shades of gameplay reminiscent of the classics of old.  Of course, when one thinks of Bastion, the name which almost always gets thrown into the same or adjacent sentence is one Logan Cunningham. Taking the role of Rucks, the game's narrator, the man's dulcet tones interspersed the gameplay with comments and references with all the near-omniscience of a storyteller. Even when you made a mistake and died, Rucks would backspace his own retelling of the tale, mentioning that 'that wasn't what happened at all'. It was the stand-out jewel in the crown of an already good game.  In Bastion's successor, Transistor, Cunningham makes a return as the leading voice, though not the game's leading role, just as he was before. This time around, he takes on the role of the near-sentient sword wielded by Red, the game's wordless lead. Like Rucks, the sword offers comment on the happenings around it but, by being a companion on the journey as it happens, his insight is more present-tense than omniscient. With the differences between Rucks and the sword, you'd be forgiven that they weren't voiced by the same man, which certainly helps to kick the game's vocal prowess up a few notches.  Unlike in Bastion, Cunningham isn't the sole voice actor. This time, the antagonists have voices of their own and, while they get nowhere near as much microphone time, they do well to avoid seeming excessively overshadowed, saying their piece and playing their respective parts as and when needed.  Anyway, enough fawning over the voices. It's the game that's important here. Transistor's aesthetic pulls just about every trick in the book to distance itself from its predecessor and, in addition to succeeding, the act of doing so allows it to stand alone. Where Bastion was a brightly lit fantasy world, Transistor takes place in the darkened, almost desolate near-modern city of Cloudbank, emphasising the deserted dystopia in which Red resides.   For the majority of the game, your only interaction with people who haven't become a disembodied voice in a sword are through faceless computer terminals, into which Red enters comments to various state-moderated news posts. While other games would have simply had the character type in a snarky one-liner to give a middle finger to the establishment, Transistor shows Red second (and even third) guessing herself as she types, often deleting a subversive message for something more unassuming, yet still expressing concern; a nice way to offer depth to a woman who can't speak.  Combat-wise, Transistor plays out a lot like Bastion, albeit with some twists thrown in for good measure. While 'The Kid' in Bastion had an array of weapons with which to dispatch foes, Red only has her sword. To make up for it, the variety comes instead in the form of abilities which are acquired - with limited scope for which are taken when - and can be used, either as direct attacks, modules to upgrade the primary attacks or equippable passive items which convey certain benefits, leading to the ability to give Red configurable loadouts.   Do you augment Crash with Breach in order to give it a longer reach? Or do you flip the two around to give Breach a stunning effect? Do you equip Help directly to gain a summonable pet? Or do you put it in the passive slot to gain the 25% chance to become a 'SuperUser' whenever you activate the game's Turn function, gaining a one-shot Kill ability which blasts all and sundry with a high-damage ball of fury?  Turn is where Transistor's combat gets a little more interesting. Reminiscent of Vagrant Story, Turn temporarily stops time and allows Red to plan out her movements and attacks, using a limited bar which spans the top of the screen. After everything has been keyed in safely, a single button press starts the flow of time up again, allowing Red to carry out her queued attacks far faster than would be possible normally. Whether its enacting a complex strategy or simply dashing away from splash damage, Turn is quite a versatile and fun system to use which fits well within the game's vaguely sci-fi world. It's one you'll be using a lot, too.  While there are some gripes about the game's length - some people likening it to about the same six-ish hours as the average Call of Duty campaign (on Veteran) - it's certainly a game well worth the look if you enjoyed Bastion, or even if you like RPG-esque games such as this. As for whether it's worth full price, that's where your mileage will vary. Some will find the better part of £15 or 20-something dollars a mite steep for a short title, while others will base their decisions on other factors. Though, with the tail end of the year coming up, it's likely to find itself on sale during the holidays.   If I recall, there's two Steam Sales left in 2014, Hallowe'en and December. And this game's already pretty fair for the price it currently is. Just imagine how appealing it'd be with a chunk off it.

I'd like to preface this by saying this is lengthy and spoiler free. If you want a more spoiler-dense, but also more critical review, I posted one in the discussion page for Transistor.  I obviously recommend this game, and I would give it a solid 7.5/10.  This game is worth your time, especially if you care far much more about mechanics than story. Now, don't get me wrong...the story is good. Not great, and CERTAINLY not Bastion, but I didn't want to shoot myself in the head playing it. I was just a little disappointed with how the story shaped up compared to its 'big brother,' so to speak.  You're Red, a singer, and she has a sword-thing called the Transistor and something big has happened. That's pretty much all you really know about the plot starting out. If you want to understand what is going on in the world, the backstory is presented in text blocks you get for using abilities in certain ways. I, honestly, was not a big fan of this at all, and will say it knocked this down from being an 8.5 to a 7.5. Sometimes it just isn't practical or desirable to use abilities in ways to unlock some text blocks, and by the end of the game (which, by the way, was just a hair too short for my likings, having paid $20).  Abilities and Turn() are the big mechanics that, to me, are super inspired. You have the option of playing the game in real-time, unleashing one of your four hotkeyed abilities (you have probably 16 or so you can pick from to hotkey) on the fly or, more in line with how the developers were hoping youd play, you can use the Turn() system, which pauses time and turns the game into a strategyish game. You get a certain amount of space to do certain moves (each of which taking different amounts of time) while at the same time planning out where your moves will launch your enemies so your subsequent attacks don't miss. The enemies really aren't ragdolls, before you get that idea, but some moves really can knock 'em out of the park. I love the Turn() system and it really lets you plan out the best way to string together attacks and combos and 'backstabs' for the highest damage bonus.  As I mentioned earlier, the abilities are a big game mechanic beyond the obvious. You have three options for deciding how to use your abilites (each of the ways you use an ability will unlock one of the ability's three backstory texts): Hotkey, Ability Modification, and Passive. You can only ever have four abilities hotkeyed, as mentioned earlier, and you can have up to two modifiers per each hotkey, and up to four passive abilities slotted. Each ability has a different hot key, modifier, or passive use. For instance, Bounce() has a bouncing effect (go figure; jumps from enemy to enemy dealing damage) when used as a hotkey, might cause your hotkeyed ability to have a branching effect when used as a modifier, or gives you a deflector shield that protects you from some damage. I find this extremely cool and really lets you customize your character to be 'yours' because there isn't really one particularly good build that outshines all the others. As you level up, you'll be able to expand your character's ability slots, so when I say 'up to four passives' and such, you have to level up to get those perks.  There exists a challenge system. I personally find it isn't as strong or 'hardcore' as Bastion's, but it does its purpose, increases exp enough to be worth it and also gives you insight to enemies when you use them. You unlock more and more as you level up.  The soundtrack is absolutely fantastic, and the little lady who did the vocals is stellar (she also sang in Bastion). The songs are haunting and really get stuck in your head. It is worth it to buy the soundtrack. So worth it.

I remember few games that made me cry. Really few. To be honest, you really dont expect that from a game. Supposedly, you play it to have fun. That´s the main reason you play games, right?  There is another reason why we do play them, however. Experience. Trying new things has always been a driving point for many things, games included. Art can be summarised as feeling new experiences, something niche that produces certain feelings. That´s a bit how I feel about Transistor.  Can´t really say much about the game that hasn´t already been said. It is simply a work of art. Even with all the commotion with the city dissapearing, the Process killing everyone and the entire world coming to an end, I couldnt help but feel that the love story between Red and the man trapped inside the Transistor was one of the driving points. I felt Red´s pain, not being able to talk or see his beloved. I also felt his pain, being trapped and alone. The connection between those two was incredible, both in the excelently realised combat and the wait time in between areas.  That´s why I cried... the ending, not to spoil it, will make you consider to what extent the love to another being can drive us to commit certain actions. Red will stay in my mind as one of the most powerful 'humming' characters in the history of gaming... that´s the least she deserves.  Thank you, folks at SuperGiant. For having created something that will stay in my memory for the longest of times. And for making me fall in love with your worlds. Thank you so much.  And, to Darren Korb... Kudos for making music that stays. That´s something that cant be achieved by mere folk.

'In Circles'  One can't help but compare Transistor to Supergiant's first effort, Bastion. Similarities jump off the screen within the first few minutes: isometric, beautiful, dynamically narrated, musically inclined, and a battle system encouraging the player to mix and match abilities and upgrades until they find that perfect playstyle. It all feels so familiar. Yet, by the end, it's clear that this game surpasses its predecessor in nearly every regard.   But here's the thing. It takes time. It's an acquired taste. The first hours left me confused, turned off by the game's apparent disregard for the player's understanding and its spare aural aesthetic. Keep at at it, though, and somewhere along the line - maybe when the ever-increasing number of powers at your disposal takes the possible combinations from 'numerous' to 'infinite', maybe when you realize the entire game is just as compelling played in real time as it is when played turn-based (or vice versa), maybe when you witness the ending - you'll realize one playthrough isn't nearly enough time spent in so entrancing a world. Even if it is ending all around you.

I haven't written a review before and this was the game that inspired me to do so. In a lot of ways it wasn't exactly what I was expecting; it was so much more. The first time I sat down to play it the story and immersion kept me playing it for hours. I didn't want to stop for any reason; I was loath to even go to the bathroom because I thought it would ruin the experience and flow that I was feeling with the game. The game explains very little directly outright and at first I was annoyed by this. But over time I realized that working out both the combat and equipment system as well as the story myself was so much more rewarding and interesting. For me it was a perfect mix of a BioShock-like story and immersion with a very customizable Final Fantasy VII-esque equipment system and a relatively unique combat system. But the best part of this game is that none of these factors are independent. In order to uncover more of the story you need to use your abilities and limiters in different combinations and ways that you otherwise wouldn't think to. In a way you take the role of detective, being told very little but able to find out almost the whole mystery. This also opens up unique ways to play as well. I discovered an awesome CC build that I used for a while because one of the tests in the Backroom forced me to use abilities I hadn't really wanted to but I realized it allowed me to lock down most enemies for a long time.  Gameplay: 9/10 Visual and Audio: 10/10 Story: 10/10  Overall: 9.5/10  Buy it, because I want to see what else Supergiant Games can do.

Ooo, didn't like the ending. Not going to spoil it though.   In story, Transistor fails in every way its predecessor, Bastion, managed to succeed. In Bastion the world comes together as you play; in transistor, it is devoid of life. Bastion did so much for a narrative, while giving out very little in concrete detail. In fact, the vagueness of Bastion is a hinge in the storytelling mechanism. For Transistor, the story never really comes together. Transistor's gameplay, in contrast, manages to innovate a fun style of isometric action, adding a little bit of slow-mo strategy and changing up the weapon modding and levelling enough to make it its own. Transistor, to me, is beautiful. If someone doubts that video games can be an art form, show them this game. The gameplay has a surprising amount of depth as well, since you can use any given 'Function' as an active ability, an upgrade to another ability, or a passive ability. It's satisfying to mix and match functions to create new abilities. What's more, the semi-turn-based gameplay works really well. You can fight in real time, then plan out a precise and devastating series of moves. And even though it's short, there are lots of ways to keep the game fresh, to extend your play time far past the first playthrough. In addition to a New Game+ playthrough, there are numerous challenges and 'limiters' you can use to customize your difficulty, reminiscent of Halo's 'skulls'.

This game is like a computer, A graceful system of components working perfectly in harmony with eachother.   The combat system is mindblowingly well crafted. Every Function() aligns perfectly with one another, Creating a massive number of different combinations and builds. This makes Transistor a very flexible game, you can -very much so- tailor the combat after your own playstyle. Whether you want to be quick and stealthy or damage dealing and tanky, Whether you want to play it in real-time or in turn-based, this game will allow you to do so, every playstyle is viable.  The story is well paced and presented in an intruiging mysterious manner, leaving you to connect the dots yourself. Reading the various logs is important if you want a grasp of what is really going on. Yet the story would be just as enjoyable if you didn't read them, although you would probably be a bit confused as to why some events occured.  The narrative is also carefully woven into the experience as a whole. There's no ludonarrative dissonance here, at least not that i noticed. The combat and things you do all makes sense within the narrative, for example; every Function() acquired is actually a digital 'trace' of a (often deceased) person. and the Function()'s nature reflects who they are (or were in life). The protagonist's trace for instance, is a disruptive stun ability, which reflects her personality as a rebellious musician who often sparks controversy with her lyrics.  This game is simply beautiful, the sound design, the art direction, the graceful combat system, the story, the acting, and all so well put together into what seems to be perfection. Every aspect of Transistor is strong. Much like a supercomputer.  Of course there will be people disagreeing with me. But mostly over things that are subjective. Mechanically and technically the game is near perfection. Most problems people would have with transistor i'd think would be subjective and down to one's individual taste.

In a world full of copied ideas and lack luster games, Transistor breathes a bit of life into the gaming industry, and is one of the best gaming experiences I have had in years.  Bioshock games is famous for dialogue choices, and thats their claim to fame. Supergiant games also has a unique signature on the gaming world. Starting with Bastion, they showed a remarkable ability to place in game narration at every turn, with no cutscenes necessary. This creates an incredibly smooth and enjoyable experience for most players.  Unlike bastion, transistor takes a more serious approach on its story. The amount of emotion in this game is just unbelievable, and the perfectly matched music only made the experience far more enjoyable for me. Even transistor's combat has a sense of uniqueness to it, as you can pause combat and line up a set of attacks to strategically defeat enemies, or just run in and smash faces.  I would definitely recomend this game to anyone looking for a new gaming experience, and definitely to everyone who enjoyed bastion. If you enjoy being able to customize abilities, transistor also hits the ball out of the park. Instead of classic stat sheets as many game have, every 'spell' or 'attack' you earn in this game can be attached to other spells to add functionality, or directly attached to your character to create passive improvements to your fights.  Despite any flaws players may find, i find that much less unique, and even blatantly mundane games, often get near perfect reviews online. With that said, giving transistor anything but a 10/10 score would not do it justice.  10/10. I definitely recommend you play this game. It's also free for PS4 Plus users for this month.

This is the first game since LIMBO that I have played that I could describe as truly, undeniably great. This game has literally everything that a game needs to have.  It has a compelling story. It is visually stunning. Seriously, this is the most gorgeous game that I have ever seen. The visuals don't need me to tell you how great they are. Just look at them.  Finally, and some would say most importantly, gameplay. I don't actually know how common this particular type of gameplay is, or if there are any other games that have used it (aside from possibly Bastion, which I will be buying as soon as I finish writing this review). But either way, its execution in this game is flawless. I loved the process of mastering the function combinations and figuring out what worked best, and that unlocking the stories behind the functions themselves encouraged you to use them in different ways and combinations. I also love the fact that the game never feels like the outcome is the result of anything aside from your skill level. I wouldn't call this a puzzle game by any means, but it definitely presents you with problems at times that require a less than direct solution.  TL;DR, this game is perfect, and you should buy it. Don't even wait for a Steam sale. Just buy it now. It's worth it.

This game is beautiful and has an excellent soundtrack. I wish I liked playing it even a quarter as much as I liked looking at and listening to it.  The combat mechanics quickly become repetitive, and the enemy design is uninspired. The game's system for swapping out your active/support/passive functions has the potential to be interesting, but for me I just ended up being disorienting as the effects of pressing the controller face buttons were constantly changing.  Overall the gameplay was a real dissapointment to me. It tries valiantly to stradle the action-oriented style of combat from Bastion with a more tactical style of combat from something like XCom. Sadly, I feel like it ends up just failing at both. The real-time combat feels mushy and you lack effective tools to avoid damage, while the turn()-based combat feels simplistic. The recharge time between turn()s is irritating and unfun.  Moreover, the constant chattering by the transistor is insufferable. Unlike the genial, pleasant storytelling vibe you got from the Bastion narrator, the transistor seems to speek just to hear his own voice. He reacts to every little thing, and frequently makes little sense. Later in the game, his resigned, grimdark commentary gets very old.  Finally, the story is much too disjointed to take seriously. It tries to evoke the sense that Cloudbank is a malliable (digital?) world and that the Process are destroying it utterly; but we don't have enough context to emote with the characters, relate to their plight, or even to understand what is happening to their world that is so catastrophic. The antagonists are a shadowy conspiracy with vague, unexplained goals; we know they have committed hubris primarily because the story template demands it. Red is a protagonist who litterly cannot speak, and the Transistor is a cipher who is also an incessant chatterbox. Your only insight into their relationship is spoken by the Transistor and is the embodyment of 'tell, don't show.' The 'dramatic' climax at the end of the game feels totally unearned; the player has no agency in it and it is actually sort of difficult to even tell what event has transpired.  If you enjoy the combat system in this game then the art and music are more than enough to carry the weak story. Sadly, I found the gameplay to be the weakest aspect in this package.  Verdict: listen to the Transistor soundtrack and buy another copy of Bastion instead.

I have really mixed feelings about this game. The gameplay was enjoyable and it was extremely pretty, with a nice soundtrack. I don't regret buying it. On the other hand, I found the story aspect both disappointing (especially the ending) and at times annoying. Also it tended to freeze up but that might just be an issue with my computer- it overheated a lot playing this. Basically, good game mechanics and visuals, mediocre story and terrible ending.  One really neat aspect is you can replay the game at the same level you ended at, with different monsters and all that. I'll admit that even though I didn't like the ending, I'm going to replay it just enough to get all my test acheivements completed, because they're kinda fun.    I wish there was an 'eh' option on reviews, but I'll just choose yes, because I wouldn't ANTI-reccomend it? I just also wouldn't rave about it to my friends. But, unable to choose between the two, I'll go with the nice option.   Spoilers ahead.  I'm a bit of an odd duck in that the story aspect of games tends to be what I go for the most and so a story I'm unhappy with is a big minus for me. For this one, I couldn't really get much of a sense of the characters or connect with them. The most characterized is the guy who lives in Red's sword, who is super into her and never shuts up. He seems nice enough, but it's really unclear whether Red even knew him before he sacrificed himself to become a sword?? If she didn't, their whole epic romance deal is even more unbelievable than it already is. Like I said, sword guy seems nice, but it takes a lot of skill to make a romance work when it's just one dude talking and the game didn't really pull it off.  The ending is what disappointed me most- basically, Red commits suicide so she can live in the virtual realm of the sword with sword guy. Like, I fought through this entire game to save and rebuild this town, and now I'm just screwing off to live in a sword. Something I did not at all need to do, because I could have just kept hanging out with him as a sword. Like, we wouldn't be able to make out but I could have taken the sword on little dates. Sit him across from me at restraunts and give him a little sword tuxedo.   Yeah, blablabla epic romance. Romanticizing suicide is always uncomfortable, but it's doubly weird when like, previously in the game two of the villains (heavily implied to be gay lovers) commit suicide and Sword Guy calls them cowards and the little fight narration even marks them as cowards, which was kinda eeesh to begin with. But then the proagonist does it and it's framed as awesome and romantic. So it's only cowardly if you're not the main character I guess? Or if you're doing it for heterosexual reasons? (That's mostly sarcastic, but then again, 3/4s of our villains ARE implied to be gay, in addition to the dudes, we've got a murderous implied-lesbian stalker). Basically, game needs to decide whether it wants to insult or glorify suicidal decisions, you can't have both.   The plot itself was a bit confusing to follow, despite being pretty standard, and aside from sword guy, we mostly know people through their character profiles. I couldn't really connect with anyone, so while it was fun game to play, it's not one I can get invested in. If you don't need to be invested in your games and are okay with going on a whole journey only for the protag to just kill herself, go for it, it's a fine game. But if either of those are red flags for you, don't do it.

8/10  + stunning visuals + good music + nice gameplay, not too difficult but challenging enough + amazing graphic/UI design and worldbuilding  - poor use of a female protagonist - disappointing ending   This is a beautifully-crafted game - stunning hand-painted visuals with good music. (I know that everyone has been raving about the music but it's personally just not to my tastes. I still think it's mostly good, though.)   There's an interesting and engaging story and the battles are a lot of fun and not too difficult. World-building is amazing - Cloudbank is a world that will stay with you and find its way into your dreams. And the graphic / UI design on this game is probably some of the best I've ever seen.  I do have issues with the game, mostly with the ending, which I found personally to be incredibly disappointing. I expected a lot more from a game with a female heroine. I expected it to adhere less to patriarchal norms and conventions, but ultimately Transistor didn't do that for me.  Still I think it's definitely worth picking up on a sale. Some people might find it worthwhile at full price - it didn't have enough story for it to warrant full price for me personally.

I liked Transistor but I didn't love Transistor. The reasons are difficult to grasp. Its similarities to Bastion run deep yet it differentiates itself more than enough to stand on its own and everything it does it does well. I guess the world just felt a little more sterile, the story not as immediately penetrable and intensely engaging. I didn't feel like the narrator was talking about what I the player was doing like in Bastion. The chemistry between the two main characters is never really established. It feels super one sided. I mean... she can't speak but I guess that's part of the challenge of the design.  It was fairly short at 9hrs and I didn't feel like I was hugely challenging myself though I only stacked 2 limiters up. Its combat was cool but maybe felt a little bit limp compared to Bastion. I liked planning ahead. I like the RPG elements. I just never felt like a badass and never felt everything flow.  The cyberpunk world of Transistor is beautifully realised. The art style is quite a departure from Bastion's lived-in, beat-up wildlands. Transistor is straight-lines and ordered geometry. Restrained and readily coherent colour schemes. Like Bastion's world unfurled in front of you there's still a sense of jazz in Transistor's aesthetics as you explore its Escher-esque spaces.  The music is some tite ♥♥♥♥ again.  Comparison to Bastion is maybe unfair but natural. The game is definitely worth getting and I am glad Supergiant Games exists and gets ♥♥♥♥ done.
