I gotta say, the story is slightly random, the pieces do come together, but there are something that you have to deduce your self, which is why I can't give it a 10/10.   The music, without a doubt, it great and fitting for the game, I liked humming to tacks in the challenge room while I took a break. The art is great, I loved how it ran at around 60fps on my low end laptop, but I still go the full experience with the beautiful effects and cut scenes. I loved how you could combine moves and mix and match to get awesome combinations, I spent our seeing all of them, and each one differs from the other, and have draw backs too, but I'd live to see that sort of style be implemented in more games, where the player can become powerful through trail and error as well as intuition rather than just levels.   Now we get to the slightly sticky part, I liked the story and people seem to adore it, but it sometimes confused me for too long, it took too long to figure out what was going on, and there were missing pieces I was expected to figure out my self. The story felt random at times, definitely not lazy, but it was hazy, the sort of haze you have at the beginning of a hard hitting drama that starts midway through the story, and at the end it feels like you're still at the beginning of that plot, you get some character development from the extra reading, but most the characters are ones you bare no attachment to, I'd like to see more flashbacks and narration of the story. So All in all it's gets a 8/10 from me, I feel like the 9/10 are from the hipsters who thought the hazy story was a great addition that simpleton could never comprehend, but I'm someone who adores story rich games so finding one with a good set up only to be left semi confused is a valid reason for me to rate it slightly lower.

Transistor is a well-made action RPG presented from an isometric perspective. One of the first things you will notice about the game is the gorgeous art direction; the main character and the enemies (called 'The Process') are represented as cel-shaded 3D models that blend perfectly with the 2D backgrounds, which depict the colorful futuristic environments of the game's setting, a city called Cloudbank. The music fits the atmosphere very well, and will change appropriately depending on what kind of a place you're wandering through. Your actions throughout the game will be narrated by your sword, the titular Transistor (or rather, the person trapped inside of it), much like how there was a narrator in Bastion (the developer's previous game). While the narrator's voice can occasionally be difficult to understand due to the sound filtering, the voice acting is still very much on key.  The biggest strength of this game, however, is certainly the deep battle system. Throughout the game, you will acquire 'functions' for the Transistor. These functions can be placed and switched around into various slots to serve three different purposes: adding a new attack, upgrading an existing attack, or adding a passive effect. Each function represents a different type of attack, and you can have up to four. Each of these attacks also has one or two upgrade slots (depending on your progression), where you can attach another function to add its own unique effect to that attack. You can also place a function in a passive slot, which will have a different effect on the player depending on the function; for example, the player may gradually recover health, or all attacks may become stronger. Not only is it very interesting to experiment with the endless amount of different combinations of functions for the Transistor, you are basically forced to experiment because whenever your life bar depletes, one of your attack functions is disabled for the next two save points (you die if you lose all four). This game also has a fair amount of replayablility due to the option to start a New Game+ after you finish, which increases the difficulty and preserves all of your functions and other sorts of progress (including your progress on the bonus challenges, which you will likely not complete in one playthrough).  I would say that the biggest drawback of Transistor is the story. While it can sometimes be interesting, at other times it can be rather difficult to understand what's going on. Maybe some people might think that parts of the story are open to the player's interpretation, but there's a point where this openness to interpretation just becomes a bunch of flat-out plot holes, and unfortunately this is the case in the game's plot. However, I believe that Transistor is one of those games where the story takes a back seat to the gameplay, so this should ultimately be a minor nuisance. This game is definitely worth a purchase, and I'm glad I played it.

tl;dr: extensive analysis of the game design. Conclusion on the bottom  So for the most part, I absolutely love this game. I will be breaking this down into the traditional pros and cons, but I will be going into detail about why certain things work and what could have been improved.  Pros + Art + Music + Style + Story + Setting + RPG Mechanics + Gameplay/Battle System  Detail: My focus here will be on the RPG mechanics and the Battle System. This, in my opinion, is some of the most wonderfuly complex and open type of RPG Character Build system I have ever played. Despite the overwhelming beginning (more on that later) the rpg system is incredibly intuitive and deep. Basically, throughout the game, you unlock active abilities called Functions. Each of these functions have three uses: The Active Ability, The Upgrade Ability, and the Passive Ability. And all three are related to the same basic Idea of the function.   The active ability as it suggests is basically using the Function as a skill (pretty straightforward).   The Upgrade aspect is what makes this game so fascinating. Basically, every Function Slot has up to two upgrades that you can insert into an active ability. So the Upgrade aspect of the Function allows you to apply the affect of the ability to ANOTHER Function. This combining of functions makes for incredible ammount of possibilities and this is where the real meat of the game is. Let's say you have a Function called 'Cull' as an active function (a hard hitting attack ability). And then you upgrade it another function called 'Tap' (when you use tap, it siphens health from the enemy). By combing it, now you have a Hard Hitting attack that siphens health. These combinations make for a game that has incredible strategic decision making and incredible bredth of uniqueness to every play style and Build. Everyone has their own combination that is completely unique and effective. The creativity on the Player's side is immense and beautiful. It's almost as if each Function is a different color of paint, and your Character Build is your canvas.  The Passive element of a Function is just as straightforward as the Active element. It gives you a passive bonus. For example: If you take the fucntion Tap (as previously mentioned) it will give you a steady health recovery.  This system is balanced in a way where there are incredible amounts of diversity and effective builds. I have never seen two similar builds. And the game encourages expermination, as it unlocks more lore for each function as you use it in a different way. The only possible issue I have with this RPG system is what I'll go into now, and that's how it is introduced to the player.  Cons: - Pacing of the Story - Pacing of Tutorial - Minimal Level design  - Shorter than it Should be  Detail: The beginning is so poorly paced that it has frustrated many people to the point of dropping the game all together, before it actually gets good. This is because of two major problems: 1. The first 30 minutes of the story. and 2.The manner in which they introduce the gameplay mechanics.  1. Let's start with what's wrong with the story. It's really pretty simple, they don't give you any sort of idea as to what you are actually doing until later. SuperGiant went with a more cryptic Noire style of story telling (which for the most part I love). It's almost like a Tarantino movie in that the story begins to unravel and make more sense the further in you get. It starts in Medius Res and the plot begins piecing itself together by the end of the game which, in general, I love. The problem is that in the beginning, it's far more cryptic than it should be, to the point of not providing the most basic of Player Motivation. They don't state where it is you are actually going or why. Even Dark Souls and Hyper Light Drifter makes the basic goal pretty clear. In this game, you don't find out where you are headed until you are already there. This is improved later in the game, but this makes it very frustrating to get invested right at the onset. If they just had the narrator say something like 'There is a bike at the edge of town, that's our ticket out of here.' Then even that would have been enough.  2. This is in my mind, the biggest problem with the game and the largest barrier to entry. The tutorial sucks. With how complex this game can get, they definitely front load the player and overload you with way too much information way too quickly. I have seen this (combined with the early difficulty of the game) turn people away. The issue is that they give you 5 Functions very early on and just sort of throw you in. They explain the basics of the combat, but with all of the Function Combinations and all the depth this game has, 5 skills is overwhelming. That's what? 25 combinations right off the bat? First off, you have to figure out what the hell these Functions even DO, and then the amount of combinations is staggering. You get the feeling that you have no idea what you are doing and your combinations are bad. This is because the Player is still trying to grasp the very unique combat mechanics of the game. This leads to what is essentially decision anxiety. Later in the game, once you get past the learning curve, everything is way more manageable (you get a new skill, read what it does, and immediately know where it will fit in your build). If the tutorial was better paced (giving you three skills instead of 5) and it showcased better how to use the skills separately and then taught you how to combine them, then this initial learning curve would have been overcome within the first 10 minutes (rather than after an hour). After that, any new skills introduced would be more manageable from the get go. I know this sounds nitpicky (and it is), but this very small negative aspect can really kill the game for people that would otherwise love it. It almost did me in, if I'm to be honest, and I love games that throw you in with very little hand holding. I feel like reducing the amount introduced to the player would simply better pace out the game.  My final criticism of the game comes down to its scope. It's small, too small (I'm not talking about story here). Sure it encourages replayability and tons of experimentation, but that's just it: The mechanics of this game are so deep and encourage so much creative experimentation, that the length and size of the game is really smaller than it deserves. You have these small linear hallways that basically lead you from battle to battle until the end. Yes, they are beautiful because of the art and it fits the focused narrative, but this game would have benefited greatly from more complex and labyrinthine level design (more like Metroidvania or Dark Souls). I understand how subjective this criticism is, however I feel this is a pretty valid view on the overall pacing of the game. This is a full on Strategic RPG, but by the time you finally feel confident with your build and you are ready to experiment with other builds, the game is over. Every element of this game encourages experimentation, except for the level design itself. If the game had a more complex design and encouraged exploration, then I feel that it would suit the mechanics much better. It could be filled with secrets that expand on the lore of the world and give you unlockables for playing around with. I dunno, it's a different game philosophy, but I feel like it would be better fit than the purely linear nature of the game. I'm not talking about a 60 hour open world rpg. I'm talking about a 15 hour metroidvania style of world design. The game ran me 9 hours, I just feel like the mechanics deserved more from the level design.   Conclusion: This game is worth it for the rpg mechanics and the battle system alone; but with the addition of beautiful art, incredible music, incredible style, and a setting that will make Cyber Punk fans drool, this game deserves a place in every library.

Transistor is Supergiant Games' second title after the amazing thing that was Bastion. With Transistor, it's certain that they really have a knack for creating unique, inspired, and fun experiences.  Transistor is a unique, inspired, and fun experience. It's easily one of the best games I've ever played, but you've heard that a thousand times before.  In Transistor you play as Red, a famous singer who as a result of some rather bizarre circumstances, has lost her voice. She picks up the Transistor, which is a cool sword that talks. Now she goes on this quest to figure out what the hell is going on and to get her voice back. The combat is something like a hack and slash combined with a strategy game. Red can have up to four skills to use, which she can attack enemies with in real time. If you push Space, you can enter Turn(). Turn() is a planning mode where time freezes. Here you can plan out Red's attacks ahead of time and then play them back, coordinating actions to clear out an entire room of enemies in one maneuver, using up portions of the Plan() bar for each action. On the downside, once you finish doing Turn(), you are extremely vulnerable and unable to defend yourself (under most circumstances) until the Plan bar refills again. It's a surprisingly unique system that manages to be enjoyable and holds a sizeable amount of depth. There are 10+ different 'Functions' you can get throughout the game, but they can be used as upgrades, passive effects, or abilities all on their own. The idea of being able to freely mix and match these abilities in nearly infinite combinations makes for a variety of gameplay styles and really brought out the inner mad scientist in me.  The story itself, while seemingly very simple to begin with, evolves to become rather complex. The Transistor talks to Red throughout her quest, sometimes about mundane things, sometimes about their situation. It serves a much different purpose than Rucks did in Bastion. Where Rucks was more of a narrator, to give insight on the world and set the mood for the story, the Transistor is more of a companion. By the end of the game, the Transistor felt like as much of a companion to me as it did to Red. You get insight into the world and Red as a character through what it says, and your interactions with it and the things around you are how the story unfolds. The way everything comes together is great and really left me satisfied with it all playing out the way it did. The story is not as straightforward as Bastion, however - to get a good understanding of all the plot elements you have to piece a lot of information together that's being given to you, and even the most subtle bits of dialogue may prove vital to comprehension. It's ultimately a very interesting tale in which I found myself getting pretty damn emotional about. For those who want to learn more, each Function is associated with a certain person in Transistor's universe, and by examining a Function after using it, you can learn more about some of the characters. This isn't integral to the story but it is a lovely and interesting extra for the people who seek it.  What should be mentioned is that the presentation is absolutely gorgeous. The UI is dripping with a neat modern tech feel, and the world has a beautiful abstract futuristic-noir aesthetic. It was so nice to see and the colors and effects in combat really popped. The soundtrack is a massive part of the experience aswell - I don't really know my genres, but I do know that it's good. It all adds to the atmosphere, and a particularly amazing touch is that using Turn() causes the song currently playing to be replaced by Red humming the melody.    Key Points
